docs.title: CabinetSense Knowledge Base
docs.text:
Welcome to the CabinetSense Knowledge Base.

Use the navigation menu to explore the documentation.

docs.title: Summary
docs.text: CabinetSense includes an AI-powered chat assistant that can answer questions about the software, help troubleshoot issues, and provide guidance on using features. The AI assistant is available through the CabinetSense web portal and understands the full range of CabinetSense features, machining operations, and workflows. The AI assistant uses your available chat time minutes. It responds in the same language as your question and can embed images, videos, and links in its responses.

docs.title: How to
docs.text: Accessing the AI Chat: Log in to the CabinetSense web portal. Navigate to the AI Chat section. The chat interface opens in a full-screen window. Using the chat: Type your question in the message box and press Send. The AI responds with an answer that may include formatted text, links to documentation, embedded images, and video references. You can ask follow-up questions in the same conversation. The conversation maintains context so you can have multi-step discussions. What you can ask about: How to use specific CabinetSense features. Troubleshooting issues with machining, materials, or export. Understanding machining database settings. Best practices for cabinet design workflows. Differences between subscription plans. How to configure preferences, templates, and profiles. Chat time: Each question and response uses chat time minutes from your account balance. Your remaining chat time is shown in your account. Additional chat time can be purchased or is included with certain subscription plans. Parent and child accounts share chat time. Language support: The AI detects the language of your question and responds in the same language. Supported languages include English, German, Hebrew, Polish, and Thai.

docs.title: FAQ
docs.text: Is the AI chat included with my subscription? Chat time availability depends on your plan. Some plans include a set amount of chat minutes. Additional minutes can be purchased. Can the AI chat see my SketchUp model? No. The AI assistant answers questions based on its knowledge of CabinetSense features and documentation. For model-specific help, contact support with your model file attached. How accurate are the AI responses? The AI is trained on CabinetSense documentation and features. For complex or unusual situations, it may recommend contacting the support team. Can I use the AI chat from within SketchUp? The AI chat is currently available through the CabinetSense web portal. Within SketchUp, you can use "Contact Support..." to reach the human support team.

docs.title: Known Issues
docs.text: The AI chat requires an internet connection and an active CabinetSense account. Very long conversations may need to be started fresh for best accuracy. Chat time is deducted even if the AI is unable to fully answer your question.

docs.title: Summary
docs.text: Your CabinetSense account is the central hub for your subscription, licences, support, and settings. This document covers how to register, manage your profile, handle multi-user subscriptions with parent and child accounts, and work with referrals and invitations.

docs.title: How to
docs.text: Creating an account: Go to the CabinetSense website and click Register. Fill in your details: email, first name, last name, company name, phone, occupation, city, province/state, country, and postal code. Choose your communication language. Agree to communication preferences. If you have a referral code, enter it during registration. You receive a welcome email with your account details and a link to tutorial videos. A 14-day trial begins automatically with full access to all features. Updating your profile: Log in to the CabinetSense web portal. Navigate to your account page. Update your personal information, company details, or communication preferences. Changes are saved immediately. Multi-user subscriptions (Parent-Child accounts): If your company needs multiple CabinetSense users, one account acts as the "parent" and others are "child" accounts. The parent account holds the subscription and licence quota (default 2, can be 3 or 4). The parent can invite team members by email. The invitation includes a link that expires after 24 hours. When a team member accepts the invitation and creates their account, they are linked to the parent's subscription. Child accounts inherit the subscription plan benefits from the parent. Chat time and training credits are shared between parent and child accounts. A child account can be set as the primary account if the company contact changes. Referral system: CabinetSense has a referral system for partners and resellers. Referral codes link new users to specific associates or partners. When you register with a referral code, you are associated with that partner for support and billing purposes. Licence quota: Each account has a licence quota that determines how many computers can run CabinetSense simultaneously. The default is 2. Purchasing additional licences through the store increases this number. You can track your registration count (how many machines are currently registered) in the Licence dialog.

docs.title: FAQ
docs.text: Can I change the email address on my account? Contact CabinetSense support to change your account email address. This needs to be done on the server side. I left my company. Can I transfer my licence to a colleague? Yes. Contact support to transfer the subscription to a new account holder. How do I invite a team member to my subscription? Log in to the web portal and navigate to client management. Enter the team member's email to send an invitation. What happens if the parent account cancels? All child accounts linked to the parent lose subscription access when the parent's subscription expires. Can I see who is using my licences? Yes. The web portal shows your registration count and linked child accounts.

docs.title: Known Issues
docs.text: Invitation links expire after 24 hours. If the recipient does not register in time, you need to send a new invitation. Changing the parent account of a child requires admin intervention. Contact support.

docs.title: Summary
docs.text: This glossary defines key terms used throughout CabinetSense. Understanding these terms helps you navigate the software and communicate with the support team effectively.

docs.title: Terms
docs.text: 32mm System: An industry-standard cabinet construction method where hardware mounting holes are placed on a 32mm grid. Ensures compatibility with European hardware manufacturers. Banding (Edge Banding): A thin strip of material applied to the exposed edges of panel parts to cover the raw edge. Coded in the cut list as EB Bottom, EB Top, EB Left, EB Right. Bifold Door: A door made of two panels hinged together that folds in half when opened. Used on wide openings and corner cabinets. BOM (Bill of Materials): A complete list of all materials, parts, and hardware needed to build the project. Bumpout: The distance a door or drawer front extends beyond the face of the cabinet box. Used for overlay door configurations. CNC (Computer Numerical Control): Automated machining using computer-controlled tools. CabinetSense exports DXF files that CNC machines read to drill holes, cut dadoes, and route profiles. Cam Lock (Confirmat): A type of mechanical fastener used in cabinet construction. Cam locks use a screw and cam mechanism to join panels. Confirmats are specialized screws for particleboard. Component (CabinetSense): A SketchUp component that CabinetSense has added cabinet-specific attributes to. It represents a single cabinet or sub-part. Construction Profile (Construction Template): A saved set of material, machining, and construction settings that can be applied to cabinets for consistency. Cut List: A CSV file listing every panel part in the project with dimensions, material, grain, banding, and machining information. Used for panel optimization and cutting. Dado: A rectangular groove cut into the surface or edge of a panel. Used to house another panel (e.g., a shelf sitting in a dado in the side panel). DXF (Drawing Exchange Format): A file format for 2D drawings that CNC machines read. CabinetSense generates one DXF per part face with all machining operations. Dynamic Component: A SketchUp component with programmable behavior. CabinetSense cabinets are Dynamic Components that respond to parameter changes. Equalize: A CabinetSense function that makes selected cabinets the same size as a reference cabinet. Face Me: An alignment option that rotates a component to always face the camera. Useful for 2D component representations in elevations. Filler Strip: A narrow piece of material used to fill gaps between cabinets or between a cabinet and a wall. Frameless (European): A cabinet construction style without a face frame. Doors and drawer fronts mount directly to the cabinet box. Common in modern and European-style kitchens. G1S (Good One Side): Sheet material (plywood, melamine) with a finished face on one side and an unfinished back. CabinetSense tracks which side faces outward. Grain Direction: The direction the wood grain runs on a panel. Important for both aesthetics and cutting — parts with grain cannot be rotated during optimization. Hinging: The machining operations for mounting hinges, including boring the cup hole in the door and drilling pilot holes in the cabinet side. Inset: A door installation where the door sits inside the cabinet opening (flush with the face of the cabinet) rather than overlaying it. Job Materials: The collection of materials assigned to a project, including sheet goods, edge banding, and hardware materials. Layout (SketchUp Layout): A companion application in SketchUp Pro for creating scaled 2D drawings and construction documents from 3D models. Line Boring: A series of evenly spaced holes drilled in a line, typically for shelf pin rows. The 32mm system uses 32mm spacing. Machining Database: The CabinetSense database that stores all machining templates, hardware specifications, and operation parameters. Machining Template: A saved configuration defining which machining operations (dadoes, hinging, line boring, fasteners, drawers, cabinet deck) are applied to a cabinet. Make Unique: Separates a cabinet from other instances of the same component definition, allowing independent editing. Millwork: Refers to 5-piece doors and mouldings made from rails, stiles, and panels. The Millwork Report lists these details. Overlay: How much a door or drawer front overlaps the cabinet box opening. Full overlay covers the entire face frame or box edge; half overlay covers half. Palette: A material color/finish selection. "Change Palette" applies a material set to cabinets. Part Number: A unique identifier assigned to each part in the project for tracking through manufacturing. Profile (Door Profile): The cross-section shape of the stile and rail edges on a 5-piece door. Defined in the Machining Database. Redraw: Regenerates the 3D geometry of a cabinet based on its current attributes. Used after changing parameters to update the visual appearance. Reveal: The gap between a door/drawer front and the cabinet box. Configured per edge (top, bottom, left, right). Scene: A saved camera position and visibility state in SketchUp. CabinetSense uses scenes for room elevations and floor plans. Scribe: A strip of material cut to fit against an uneven surface (usually a wall). Scribe edges are marked in the cut list. Stile: The vertical members of a 5-piece door frame. Left stile and right stile. Rail: The horizontal members of a 5-piece door frame. Top rail and bottom rail. Tag (Layer): SketchUp's visibility control system. CabinetSense creates tags for different cabinet groups for toggling visibility. Verify Model Integrity: A CabinetSense diagnostic that checks all cabinets for data consistency, missing attributes, and construction errors. Wall Protrusion: An obstacle on a wall (baseboard, pipe, etc.) that cabinet parts need to be notched around. Z-Zero: The reference point for depth measurements in CNC machining. Can be set to the top or bottom of the material.

docs.title: Summary
docs.text: CabinetSense offers three subscription tiers that progressively unlock more features. Understanding which plan gives you which features helps you choose the right one for your needs. This document covers the plans, what each includes, how credits work, and how to manage your subscription.

docs.title: How to
docs.text: Available plans: Essentials (Designer): Entry-level plan for 3D cabinet design. Full 3D cabinet design and visualization. Component library access. Scene management and tags. Preset styles. Dimension tools. Online help and support. Plus (Cutlist): Mid-tier plan for design and production planning. Everything in Essentials. Cut list export (CSV). Drawer box report. Hardware report. Material summary. Job Materials and Material Review. Grain detection. Professional (CNC): Full-featured plan for CNC manufacturing. Everything in Plus. DXF machining files for CNC machines. Full Machining Database access (create and edit templates). Millwork report. Advanced machining preview. EnRoute compatibility. Trial period: New accounts get a 14-day free trial with full access to all features. After the trial, you choose a plan or features become restricted. A special 3-Month Trial is also available for the Professional plan, which includes 120 minutes of prepaid training. Credits system: CabinetSense uses a credits system for certain operations. Active subscribers have unlimited credits (effectively unlimited exports). Credit types: Paid Credits: Purchased credit packages (1500 or 4000 credits). Daily Credits: Free credits awarded daily. Monthly Credits: Free credits awarded monthly. Open Balance: Additional credits. Credits are consumed in this order: Daily, Monthly, Open, then Paid. Chat time and training credits: Some plans include AI chat time (measured in minutes). Prepaid Training minutes can be purchased separately and used to book training sessions. The 3-Month Trial includes 120 minutes of prepaid training. Priority Support: Available as an add-on to any plan. Provides faster response times and dedicated calendar slots for appointments. Increases your support level for priority handling. Managing your subscription: View your plan status in the Licence dialog in SketchUp or on the web portal. Upgrade or downgrade through the CabinetSense store (Buy...). Cancellation can be done through the web portal. Your plan remains active until the end of the current billing period.

docs.title: FAQ
docs.text: Can I switch plans mid-subscription? Yes. You can upgrade at any time and the price difference is prorated. Downgrading takes effect at the next billing cycle. What happens to my credits if I cancel? Paid credits remain until used. Daily and monthly credits stop being awarded when your subscription expires. Do credits expire? Paid credits do not expire as long as your account is active. Daily credits reset each day and monthly credits reset each month. What features are restricted after trial expiry? You can still open and view your models, but export, machining, and reporting features require an active subscription. Can I buy credits without a subscription? Yes. Credit packages can be purchased separately for pay-as-you-go usage.

docs.title: Known Issues
docs.text: If your subscription lapses and you renew, there may be a short delay before your plan features are restored. Restart SketchUp after renewing.

docs.title: Summary
docs.text: This guide covers common issues CabinetSense users encounter and how to resolve them. If your issue is not listed here, use the Contact Support feature (CabinetSense > Help > Contact Support...) to reach the support team.

docs.title: Common Issues and Solutions
docs.text: CabinetSense does not load when I open SketchUp: Check that the CabinetSense folder is in the correct SketchUp Plugins directory. On Mac: ~/Library/Application Support/SketchUp [year]/SketchUp/Plugins/CabinetSense/ On Windows: C:\Users[username]\AppData\Roaming\SketchUp\SketchUp [year]\SketchUp\Plugins\CabinetSense\ Verify your licence is active by going to CabinetSense > Help > Licence... Restart SketchUp after installing or updating CabinetSense. "Licence expired" or "Licence not found" message: Your subscription may have lapsed. Check your account on the CabinetSense web portal. If you recently renewed, restart SketchUp to refresh the licence. Check your internet connection — CabinetSense validates the licence online. If you changed computers, you may need to register the new device. Export button is greyed out or export produces empty files: Make sure you have an active subscription that includes the export features you need (Plus for cut list, Professional for DXF). Ensure there are visible CabinetSense cabinets in the model. Hidden or tagged-off cabinets are not exported. Run Verify Model Integrity (CabinetSense > Model > Verify Model Integrity) to check for data issues. DXF files show incorrect hole positions: Verify the correct machining template is assigned to the affected cabinets. Check the Z-axis zero setting in Preferences matches your CNC machine setup. Run Machining Preview (CabinetSense > Multi-Component > Preview Machining) to visually verify the machining on screen before exporting. If holes are mirrored, check the Flip Operation Direction in CNC Machine preferences. Materials do not appear correctly: Run Material Review (CabinetSense > Model > Material Review) to check material assignments. Ensure materials have been assigned through Job Materials, not just painted with the SketchUp Paint Bucket. If G1S materials show the wrong side, use G1S Material Review to flip them. Cabinets look wrong after upgrading CabinetSense: Run Model Conversion (CabinetSense > Upgrade Model) to update the model to the new version. After conversion, run Verify Model Integrity. If issues persist, try Redraw (CabinetSense > Multi-Component > Redraw) on the affected cabinets. SketchUp is slow with large CabinetSense models: Disable real-time observers: In Preferences, turn off Model Integrity Checking (automatic) and set Scene Management to manual. Hide construction lines: CabinetSense > Model > Delete Construction Lines. Use scenes with limited visible tags to reduce what SketchUp renders. Turn off Drawer Open Indicator in Preferences if not needed. Layout export fails or produces blank pages: Save your model before running Send to Layout. Make sure you have SketchUp Pro with Layout installed. Check that scenes are properly set up before exporting. Try Raster render mode instead of Vector — Vector mode can fail on very complex models. Changes to one cabinet affect other cabinets: This happens when cabinets share the same component definition. Use Make Unique (CabinetSense > Multi-Component > Make Unique) to give each cabinet its own definition before making changes. Machining preview shows no machining: Ensure a machining template is assigned to the cabinet. Check through the Machining Database or Component Options. Verify the machining template has operations defined (dadoes, hinging, line boring, etc.). Clear and re-preview: CabinetSense > Multi-Component > Clear Machining Preview, then Preview Machining again.

docs.title: FAQ
docs.text: How do I contact support? Go to CabinetSense > Help > Contact Support... This opens a support form that automatically includes your system information. Where are CabinetSense log files? Log files are created in the SketchUp Plugins/CabinetSense folder. Look for files with .log extensions. How do I check my CabinetSense version? Go to CabinetSense > Machining Application > About. The version number is displayed. Can I roll back to a previous version? Contact support for access to previous versions. Keep a backup of your Plugins folder before updating.

docs.title: Functions
docs.text:
Welcome to the Functions section.

Use the navigation menu on the left to explore the available topics.

docs.title: Change Door, Drawer Front, and Panel Dialog
Summary
docs.text: The "Change Door/DF/Panel..." dialog is a powerful tool for configuring doors, drawer fronts, and panels across one or more cabinets at once. It is accessed via CabinetSense > Multi-Component > Change Door/DF/Panel... This dialog lets you control the door style, grain direction, panel banding, handle type and position, reveals (gaps), and stile/rail widths for 5-piece doors.

docs.title: How to
docs.text: Opening the dialog: Select one or more cabinets in your model. Go to CabinetSense > Multi-Component > Change Door/DF/Panel... Component selection: Choose which component types to change: Door, Drawer Front, Panel, Except Panel, or All. Choose position filtering: Only Top, Except Top, or All. This lets you target only top doors on multi-door cabinets. Specification section: Style: Choose Slab (flat panel) or 5-Piece (rails and stiles with center panel). Grain Direction: Width (horizontal grain) or Height (vertical grain). Panel Banding: None, Exposed, Semi-exposed, Concealed, or Scribe. This affects the cut list banding information. Profile: Select the door profile for 5-piece doors (defined in the Machining Database). Arch: None, Full, or Half. For arched-top doors. Handle section: Handle Type: None, Knob, or Handle. Number of Handles: One or Two. Door Handle Location: 9 positions (top-left, top-center, top-right, middle-left, center, middle-right, bottom-left, bottom-center, bottom-right). Drawer Handle Location: Same 9 positions. Drawer Handle Orientation: Horizontal or Vertical. Handle Default Distance: Zero (handle sits at the exact position) or 1/2 Stile/Rails (handle is offset by half the stile/rail width). Handle Side Distance: Custom horizontal offset from the edge. Handle Top/Bottom Distance: Custom vertical offset from the edge. Reveals section: Left Reveal: Gap between the left edge of the door and the cabinet. Right Reveal: Gap on the right edge. Top Reveal: Gap at the top. Bottom Reveal: Gap at the bottom. Door/Drawer Gap: The gap between adjacent doors or between a door and drawer front. Bumpout: How far the door extends beyond the face of the cabinet. Inset: How far the door is recessed into the cabinet opening (for inset doors). Stile and Rail widths (5-piece doors only): Left Stile Width, Right Stile Width. Top Rail Width, Bottom Rail Width. Mid Stile Width, Mid Rail Width (for doors with divisions).

docs.title: FAQ
docs.text: Can I change just the handles without changing the door style? Yes. Set the door style fields to their current values and only change the handle settings. What is the difference between Bumpout and Inset? Bumpout is for overlay doors where the door face extends beyond the cabinet face. Inset is for inset doors where the door sits inside the cabinet opening. Can I set different reveals for doors and drawer fronts? The reveals apply to all components matching your Component selection. To set different values for doors vs. drawer fronts, run the dialog twice with different Component selections. What do the handle position options mean? The 9 positions form a 3x3 grid on the door face. For example, "bottom-right" places the handle near the bottom-right corner of the door. The Side Distance and Top/Bottom Distance values fine-tune the exact position.

docs.title: Known Issues
docs.text: Applying changes to many cabinets at once may take a moment. A progress indicator shows the status. When switching from Slab to 5-Piece style, make sure a valid profile is selected in the Machining Database.

docs.title: Summary
docs.text: The Component menu contains functions that operate on a single selected CabinetSense component. These let you edit component properties, adjust cabinet openings, align parts, toggle door behavior, and more. You must select exactly one CabinetSense component in the model before using these functions. The Component menu is found under CabinetSense > Component. There is also a CS Component toolbar.

docs.title: How to
docs.text: Component Options: Select a CabinetSense component and go to CabinetSense > Component > Component Options. This opens the CabinetSense Component Options panel, which shows all the configurable properties for that component (dimensions, materials, room number, etc.). This replaces the standard SketchUp Dynamic Components dialog. Equalize Door/Drawer Heights: Select a cabinet and go to CabinetSense > Component > Equalize Door/Drawer Heights. This adjusts the heights of doors and drawer fronts within the cabinet to be equal. Vertical Cabinet Openings: Changes the heights of the openings within a cabinet (e.g., adjusting shelf positions). Horizontal Cabinet Openings: Changes the widths of the openings within a cabinet (e.g., adjusting partition positions). Fill...: Fills an open space in the model with the selected component. Useful for filling gaps between cabinets. Resize...: Changes the overall dimensions of the selected component. Face Me: Rotates the selected component to face the current camera view. Align: Toggles alignment mode for the selected component. Toggle Door Opening: Toggles the swing direction of a door (left-to-right or right-to-left). Toggle Number of Doors: Toggles between one door and two doors on the selected cabinet. Reconnect Component: Reconnects a component that has become disconnected from its parent cabinet. This can happen if you manually move a part. Transform: Transforms a standard SketchUp component into a CabinetSense part so it can be recognized and processed during export.

docs.title: FAQ
docs.text: What is the difference between Component Options and SketchUp's Dynamic Components dialog? Component Options is CabinetSense's own panel that understands cabinet-specific properties. It replaces the standard Dynamic Components dialog for CabinetSense components. When would I use Transform? When you have a SketchUp component (like a custom panel or fixture) that you want CabinetSense to recognize and include in exports. What does Reconnect Component do? It re-establishes the link between a child part (like a shelf or door) and its parent cabinet. This link can break if parts are manually moved.

docs.title: Known Issues
docs.text: Most Component functions require exactly one component to be selected. If you have zero or multiple components selected, the function may not be available.

docs.title: Summary
docs.text: The Cutlist Export and CNC Machine sections in Preferences control how cut list CSV files are formatted and how CNC-related settings are applied. These settings affect delimiter characters, oversize allowances, pre-mill removal, small part filtering, and machine-specific layout options. These settings are configured in CabinetSense > Model > Preferences under the "Cutlist Export" and "CNC Machine" categories.

docs.title: How to
docs.text: Cutlist Export settings: CSV Delimiter: Choose the character that separates columns in the CSV file. Options include comma (,), semicolon (;), or tab. Use the delimiter your panel optimization software expects. Small Part Width: The minimum width for a part to be included in the cut list. Parts narrower than this are excluded. Useful for filtering out trivial parts like edge strips. Pre-Mill Removal: An amount subtracted from each dimension to account for pre-milling (surfacing) the sheet goods before cutting. For example, if you pre-mill 1mm off each face, set this to 2mm. Oversize Amount: An amount added to each dimension for oversize cutting. Useful when you want parts cut slightly larger for final trimming. CNC Machine settings: Layout Orientation: Landscape or Portrait. Controls how parts are oriented relative to the CNC bed in the DXF output. Z-Axis Zero: Top of Part or Bottom of Part (as described in DXF Export Settings). Flip Operation Direction: How the part is flipped for second-side machining. These settings should match your CNC machine's physical setup. Best practices: Match the CSV delimiter to your optimization software (CutRite, Mozaik, OptiCut, etc.). Set oversize and pre-mill to match your shop practices. Verify the CNC machine settings by exporting a test part and checking it in your CNC software before running a full project.

docs.title: FAQ
docs.text: What delimiter should I use? Comma is most common. If your software is European and uses commas as decimal separators, use semicolon instead. What is a good oversize amount? Typically 1-2mm (or 1/16" to 1/8"). This depends on your shop's workflow and whether parts are edge-banded before or after trimming. Can I filter out hardware from the cut list? The cut list only includes panel parts. Hardware is reported separately in the Hardware Report.

docs.title: Known Issues
docs.text: Changing the delimiter after importing into optimization software may cause errors. Ensure the delimiter matches before import.

docs.title: Summary
docs.text: DXF Export settings control how CabinetSense generates DXF machining files for your CNC machine. These settings determine the file format version, machining granularity, optimization, Z-axis behavior, and how double-sided parts are handled. Properly configuring these settings ensures your CNC software reads the files correctly and your parts are machined accurately. DXF settings are configured in CabinetSense > Model > Preferences > DXF Export.

docs.title: How to
docs.text: DXF version: CabinetSense can output DXF in multiple format versions. AC1009 (AutoCAD R12): Widely compatible with most CNC software including older machines. AC1021 (AutoCAD 2007): Supports newer features but may not work with all CNC controllers. If unsure, use AC1009 for maximum compatibility. Z-axis zero: Top of Part: Z-zero is at the top surface of the material. Drill depths go downward (negative Z). This is the most common setting. Bottom of Part: Z-zero is at the bottom surface. Drill depths go upward (positive Z). Used with some CNC setups where the spoilboard is the reference. Granularity: Controls the resolution of curves in the DXF output. Higher granularity produces smoother curves but larger files. Lower granularity produces smaller files with slightly faceted curves. Default settings work well for most CNC machines. Optimization: Multiple optimization methods are available for tool path efficiency. Optimization reduces unnecessary tool movements and can speed up machining. Multi-pass: For deep cuts (dadoes, rabbets), multi-pass splits the operation into multiple shallow passes. Configure the maximum cut depth per pass based on your tooling and material. Flip operation direction: Controls how double-sided parts are handled. When a part has machining on both sides, CabinetSense generates two DXF files (Side 1 and Side 2). The flip direction determines whether the part is flipped left-to-right or top-to-bottom when machining the second side. Layout orientation: Sets whether parts are laid out in landscape or portrait orientation on the CNC bed. 3D DXF: Enables full 3D DXF output with Z-axis depth information. Some CNC software requires 3D DXF for proper tool depth processing. Vectric compatibility: CabinetSense DXF files are compatible with Vectric VCarve and Aspire. Vectric Gadget compatibility can be enabled for automated workflow integration.

docs.title: FAQ
docs.text: Which DXF version should I use? Start with AC1009 (R12). It works with virtually all CNC software. Only switch to AC1021 if your software specifically requires it. Should I use Top or Bottom Z-zero? Most CNC machines reference from the top of the material. Use "Top of Part" unless your CNC documentation specifies otherwise. My CNC software shows garbled curves. What should I do? Increase the DXF granularity setting. This produces smoother curve representations. What is the flip direction for? When you machine both sides of a part, you physically flip it on the CNC bed. The flip direction tells CabinetSense how you flip it so the second-side holes line up with the first side.

docs.title: Known Issues
docs.text: Some CNC software may not support all DXF entity types. If you see missing features in your CNC software, try a different DXF version.

docs.title: Summary
docs.text: The Document menu contains tools for creating construction documents, adding dimensions, managing part numbers, and exporting to SketchUp Layout. These help you prepare professional drawings and documentation for your cabinet projects. The Document menu is found under CabinetSense > Document. There is also a CS Document toolbar.

docs.title: How to
docs.text: Send to Layout...: Go to CabinetSense > Document > Send to Layout... This exports your SketchUp model to a SketchUp Layout document. CabinetSense arranges scenes on pages, applies a Layout template, and sets scale and render mode. Options include: Layout name, model scale, render mode (Raster, Hybrid, Vector), and whether to include project and floor scenes. Add Outside Dimensions: Adds plan-view (outside) dimensions to selected cabinets showing overall width, height, and spacing. Add Inside Dimensions: Adds elevation-view (inside) dimensions showing opening sizes, shelf positions, and internal measurements. Clear Dimensions: Removes dimensions that were added by CabinetSense. Renumber Parts: Renumbers all part numbers in the model sequentially. Assign Part #'s: Activates the Part Tool which lets you assign part numbers by clicking on parts in the model. Show Part Numbers: Displays part number labels on all parts in the model. Clear Part Numbers: Removes all part number labels from the model. Change Prefix: Changes the room number prefix for selected cabinets. Find Part Number: Highlights a specific part in the model by its part number.

docs.title: FAQ
docs.text: Do I need SketchUp Layout to use Send to Layout? Yes. Send to Layout requires SketchUp Pro with Layout installed (SketchUp 2018 or later). What format are the dimensions? Dimensions use the units configured in CabinetSense Preferences (SketchUp Model Units, Inches, or Millimeters). Do part numbers persist between sessions? Yes. Part numbers are stored as attributes on the components and persist when you save and reopen the model.

docs.title: Known Issues
docs.text: Send to Layout requires the model to be saved first. You will be prompted to save if you have not already. Add Outside/Inside Dimensions work best when cabinets are aligned along walls.

docs.title: Summary
docs.text: The Help submenu provides access to documentation, tutorials, video resources, and the CabinetSense website. It is found under CabinetSense > Help. It also includes options to download the latest library and materials, reinstall the software, and view release notes.

docs.title: How to
docs.text: Get the latest Library...: Downloads the latest CabinetSense component library (cabinet templates, hardware). Get the latest Materials Library...: Downloads the latest material textures and configurations. Reinstall CabinetSense...: Downloads and reinstalls the full CabinetSense application. Online Help: Opens the CabinetSense online help wiki in your browser. Release Notes: Opens the release notes showing what is new in the latest version. Getting Started Help: Opens the Getting Started guide for new users. Videos: Opens the CabinetSense YouTube channel with tutorial and bootcamp videos. Website: Opens the CabinetSense website.

docs.title: FAQ
docs.text: Is an internet connection required for help? Yes. Online Help, Videos, and Website require an internet connection. The library and materials downloads also require internet access. Where can I find video tutorials? Go to CabinetSense > Help > Videos. This opens the CabinetSense YouTube channel.

docs.title: Known Issues
docs.text: "Get the latest Library..." and "Get the latest Materials Library..." are disabled when running a special edition of CabinetSense.

docs.title: Summary
docs.text: "Send to Layout..." creates a SketchUp Layout document from your CabinetSense model, automatically arranging scenes on pages with proper scaling, dimensions, and title blocks. It is accessed via CabinetSense > Document > Send to Layout... This feature requires SketchUp Pro 2018 or later with Layout installed.

docs.title: How to
docs.text: Preparing for Layout export: Make sure your model is saved (Layout export requires a saved .skp file). Set up your scenes using Scene Management or manually. Make sure your Job Information is filled in (Project Title, Client Name, etc.) as these appear in the Layout document. Running the export: Go to CabinetSense > Document > Send to Layout... A dialog appears with the following options: Layout Name: The filename for the Layout document. Model Scale: Choose from No Scale, 1:4, 1:5, 1:8, 1:10, 1:12, 1:15, 1:20, 1:25, or 1:30. Render Mode: Raster (fastest, pixel-based), Hybrid (mix of raster and vector), or Vector (cleanest lines, slowest). Place Current Scene on Cover Page: Includes the current camera view on the first page. Export Project Scene: Includes a project overview scene. Export Floor Scene: Includes a floor plan scene. Line Weight: Controls the thickness of lines in the Layout document. What gets created: A Layout document (.layout file) with: A cover page with project information and the 3D view. Individual pages for each room scene. Pages for floor plans if enabled. Auto-text fields populated from job information. A drawing area with the correct scale applied. Layout templates: CabinetSense uses Layout templates to define the page style, title block, borders, and logo placement. You can customize the template to match your company branding.

docs.title: FAQ
docs.text: Do I need SketchUp Pro? Yes. Send to Layout requires SketchUp Pro with Layout installed. Can I edit the Layout document after export? Yes. The exported file is a standard Layout document that you can open and edit in Layout. Which render mode should I use? Raster is fastest and good for drafts. Hybrid gives clean lines for dimensions while keeping textures. Vector gives the cleanest output but takes the longest. How do I customize the Layout template? Create or modify a Layout template file (.layout) and place it in your CabinetSense templates folder. Contact support for guidance on template customization.

docs.title: Known Issues
docs.text: Very large models may take a long time to render in Vector mode. Use Raster or Hybrid for faster results. The model must be saved before exporting. If unsaved, you will be prompted.

docs.title: Summary
docs.text: The Multi-Component menu contains functions that operate on one or more selected CabinetSense components at the same time. These are your batch operations — changing doors across multiple cabinets, previewing machining, switching handles, adjusting materials, and more. Select one or more CabinetSense components, then use these functions. The Multi-Component menu is found under CabinetSense > Multi-Component. There is also a CS Multi Component toolbar.

docs.title: How to
docs.text: Change Door/DF/Panel...: Select one or more cabinets and go to CabinetSense > Multi-Component > Change Door/DF/Panel... A dialog opens where you can change the door style (Slab or 5-Piece), grain direction, panel banding, profile, arch style, handle type and position, reveals, and gap settings. Changes apply to all selected cabinets. Preview Machining: Select one or more cabinets and go to CabinetSense > Multi-Component > Preview Machining. CabinetSense generates a 3D preview of all machining operations (drill holes, dadoes, etc.) directly in the model so you can visually verify before exporting. Clear Machining: Removes the 3D machining preview from selected cabinets. Choose New Drawer System...: Changes the drawer slide system for selected cabinets. Choose New Handle...: Changes the handle or knob for doors and drawer fronts on selected cabinets. Change Palette...: Changes the material palette (material assignments) for selected cabinets. This overrides the global Job Materials settings for those specific cabinets. Change Height...: Changes the overall height of selected cabinets. Redraw: Recalculates and redraws the selected components. Use this after changing attributes or if a component appears incorrect. Private Layer: Assigns selected components to a private layer for organization. Toggle Closet Parts: Turns backs on or off for closet-type cabinets. Apply Construction Profile: Applies a saved construction profile (template) to selected cabinets. A construction profile defines the entire construction specification including material types, machining template, connector faces, and grain directions. Make Unique: Makes the selected components unique so that modifying one does not affect other copies. Hide/Unhide: Hides or unhides the selected components. Create Connector: Transforms a cabinet into a connector component for joining cabinets together.

docs.title: FAQ
docs.text: Can I use these functions with Cabinet Groups? Yes. Select a group from the Cabinet Groups panel, and the multi-component operation applies to all cabinets in that group. What is the difference between Change Palette and Job Materials? Job Materials assigns materials globally by type. Change Palette overrides materials on specific selected cabinets. What does Redraw do? It recalculates all formulas and redraws the component geometry. Use it when a component does not look right or after changing attributes.

docs.title: Known Issues
docs.text: Preview Machining on many cabinets at once can be slow and add significant geometry to the model. Clear Machining to remove the preview when done. Make Unique creates new component definitions, which increases file size.

docs.title: Summary
docs.text: Part Labels and Edge Labels are visual annotations that CabinetSense can display on cabinet parts in the SketchUp model. Part Labels show the part number, description, or dimensions directly on each part. Edge Labels show edge banding codes, drilling indicators, and material codes on each edge. These labels help you visually verify which parts need banding, which edges have machining, and what part numbers are assigned. Labels are configured in CabinetSense > Model > Preferences under "Part Label Text" and "Edge Label Text."

docs.title: How to
docs.text: Part Label settings: Height: The text height for part labels. Larger values make labels easier to read but can clutter small parts. Include Part Number: Toggle whether the part number appears on the label. Truncation: Limit label length for cleaner display. Long descriptions are truncated to fit. Edge Label settings: Banding Codes: Edge banding is shown using codes that indicate which edges have banding applied. Drilling Codes: Edges with drill operations are marked with specific codes. Character Placeholders: Custom characters can represent different edge conditions (banded, unbanded, drilled, etc.). Displaying labels: Labels appear in the model when Part Numbers (CabinetSense > Document > Part Numbers) or Machining Preview is active. Toggle label visibility through the CabinetSense menu. Reading edge banding codes: Each edge is coded with a letter or number indicating its banding status. Common codes: 0: No banding. 1: Standard banding. 2: Thick banding. X: Scribe banding. The codes appear on the four edges: Bottom, Top, Left, Right (matching the cut list columns EB Bottom, EB Top, EB Left, EB Right).

docs.title: FAQ
docs.text: Can I print the part labels? Part labels are visible in SketchUp's rendered views and can be captured in scenes. Export the scene to Layout or print directly from SketchUp. How do I change the edge banding code for a specific edge? Edge banding is configured through the Machining Database and Change Door dialog. Individual edges can be modified through Component Options. Are labels included in the DXF export? Part labels can optionally be included in DXF files for CNC machine identification. This is controlled by the DXF export settings.

docs.title: Known Issues
docs.text: Very small parts may have labels that extend beyond the part boundary. Reduce the label height in preferences to mitigate.

docs.title: Summary
docs.text: Presets let you quickly switch between different visual styles and tag combinations. The Presets menu is found under CabinetSense > Presets. There is also a CS Presets toolbar. Presets come in two types: Style presets (which change the visual appearance) and Tag presets (which change which tags are visible).

docs.title: How to
docs.text: Style Presets: Concept Style: A clean, minimal look for initial design concepts. Design Style: A refined look for design presentation. Construction Style: Shows construction details and connections. Diagram Style: A technical diagram view. Presentation Style: A polished look for client presentations. Tag Presets: Carcass tags: Shows only the carcass/box parts. Frontage tags: Shows doors, drawer fronts, and panels. Drawer tags: Shows drawer-related parts. External Parts tags: Shows external/visible parts only. Room Only tags: Shows parts for the current room only. Hide Room tags: Hides room-specific parts. Presentation tags: A curated set of visible tags for client presentations. Using presets: Go to CabinetSense > Presets and click any preset. Or use the CS Presets toolbar for one-click access. The style or tag visibility changes immediately.

docs.title: FAQ
docs.text: Can I create my own presets? Custom style and tag preset configurations can be saved through CabinetSense Preferences. Do presets affect the export? No. Presets are visual only. Exports process all components regardless of preset.

docs.title: Known Issues
docs.text: Switching presets changes the current SketchUp rendering style. If you have custom SketchUp styles, they may be overridden.

docs.title: Summary
docs.text: The Profiles menu lets you save and load cabinet construction profiles, and outline door/moulding profiles in the model. A construction profile is a saved set of construction specifications that can be applied to cabinets — it includes material types, machining templates, connector configurations, grain directions, and more. The Profiles menu is found under CabinetSense > Profiles. There is also a CS Profile toolbar.

docs.title: How to
docs.text: Open Profile...: Go to CabinetSense > Profiles > Open Profile... Browse and select a previously saved construction profile to load. Save Profile...: Go to CabinetSense > Profiles > Save Profile... Saves the current construction specification as a named profile for reuse. Outline Outside Profile: Draws the outside profile outline on selected 5-piece doors in the model. Outline Inside Profile: Draws the inside profile outline on selected 5-piece doors. Outline Applied Moulding Profile: Draws the applied moulding profile outline. Outline Panel Profile: Draws the panel profile outline on selected doors.

docs.title: FAQ
docs.text: What is saved in a construction profile? Cabinet style, construction zones, material types, machining template, connector faces, grain directions, reveals, and sub-component configurations. Can I share profiles with other users? Yes. Profile files are stored in the Styles Folder configured in Preferences. Copy the file to another user's Styles Folder.

docs.title: Known Issues
docs.text: Profile outlines are visual overlays. They do not affect machining output directly.

docs.title: Summary
docs.text: CabinetSense generates several types of reports when you run Export... from the Model menu. Each report covers a different aspect of your cabinet project. The reports available depend on your subscription plan. This document explains what each report contains and how to use it.

docs.title: How to
docs.text: Cut List Report (CSV): Generated for: Cutlist/Plus and CNC/Professional plans. Contains one row per part with columns for: Part Number, Sub-Assembly (cabinet name), Description, Number of Copies. Thickness, Width, Length. Material Type, Material Name. Can Rotate (whether the part can be rotated during panel optimization — based on grain direction). Banding (edge banding on each edge). Parent Name (the cabinet this part belongs to). Drilling (whether the part has machining operations, shown as 0 or 1). Model (the SketchUp model name). Edge Banding details: EB Bottom, EB Top, EB Left, EB Right. Machining flag. Tag, Instance Name. DXF File (the name of the corresponding DXF file if CNC machining is generated). Export settings like Oversize Amount and Pre-Mill Removal are applied to the dimensions. DXF Machining Files: Generated for: CNC/Professional plan only. One DXF file per part face (side 1 and side 2 for double-sided parts). Contains all machining operations: drill holes, dadoes, routing paths, profiles. Multiple dado types are supported (through dadoes, blind dadoes, lock rabbets, etc.). Z-zero can be set to Top of Part or Bottom of Part. Compatible with most CNC software including Vectric products and EnRoute. Labels can be included with part numbers and names. Drawer Box Report: Generated for: Cutlist/Plus and CNC/Professional plans. Lists every drawer box in the project with: Part name, Description, Material. Width, Depth, Height. Bottom thickness, Walls thickness. Notch Front dimensions. Slide system used. Hardware Report: Generated for: Cutlist/Plus and CNC/Professional plans. Lists all hardware with: Assembly (which cabinet), Group, Part, Description. Quantity. Width, Height, Thickness. Parent Name, Model. Millwork Report: Generated for: CNC/Professional plan only. Covers 5-piece doors and applied mouldings with: Style (Slab or 5-Piece), Grain direction. Stile widths: Left Stile, Right Stile. Rail widths: Top Rail, Bottom Rail, Mid Stile, Mid Rail. Panel Insert, Panel Thickness. Lite Rows, Lite Columns (for glass doors). Arch type. Door Opening direction. Bifold flag. Estimate Report: Includes project information: Version, Client, Project Title. Lists items with Quantity, Width, Height, Depth, and Group. Useful for quoting and project planning.

docs.title: FAQ
docs.text: Can I customize which columns appear in the cut list? The cut list format is standardized for compatibility with panel optimization software. However, since it is a CSV file, you can open it in Excel and reorder or remove columns as needed. What CNC software is compatible with the DXF files? CabinetSense DXF files are compatible with most CNC software including Vectric VCarve and Aspire, EnRoute, AlphaCAM, Cabinet Vision, and general-purpose DXF readers. Can I generate reports for just one cabinet? The export processes all visible cabinets. Use scenes and tags to control visibility if you only want specific cabinets.

docs.title: Known Issues
docs.text: The DXF file list in the cut list only appears for parts that have machining operations assigned. Hardware quantities are calculated based on the machining database configuration. If hardware is manually placed in SketchUp without using CabinetSense, it will not appear in the hardware report.

docs.title: Summary
docs.text: The Tags menu controls the visibility of different part types in your model by toggling SketchUp tags (formerly called layers). CabinetSense automatically organizes parts onto tags so you can quickly show or hide specific categories like doors, drawer fronts, carcass parts, hardware, and more. The Tags menu is found under CabinetSense > Tags. There is also a CS Tags toolbar with an icon for each tag.

docs.title: How to
docs.text: Toggling individual tags: Go to CabinetSense > Tags and select any of the following to show or hide that category: Wall Tag Door Tag Drawer Front Tag Pullout Front Tag Drawerbox Tag Faceframe Tag Carcass Tags Swing Tag Pattern Tag Machining Tag Panel Tag Filler Tag Countertop Tag Hardware Tag Decor Tag Lights Tag Room Tag Toggling all CabinetSense tags: Go to CabinetSense > Tags > CabinetSense Tags. This toggles all CabinetSense-managed tags on or off at once. Using the toolbar: The CS Tags toolbar provides quick one-click access to each tag toggle.

docs.title: FAQ
docs.text: What are tags used for? Tags control visibility. For example, hide the Door Tag to see inside the cabinets, or hide the Carcass Tags to focus on just the doors and drawer fronts. Do tags affect the export? No. The export processes all CabinetSense components regardless of tag visibility. Tags are for visual control only. How does CabinetSense assign tags? CabinetSense automatically assigns tags to parts when they are created or redrawn. You do not need to manually assign tags.

docs.title: Known Issues
docs.text: If you manually change a part's tag assignment in SketchUp, CabinetSense may reassign it during the next redraw.

docs.title: Summary
docs.text: The 32mm Build System is an industry-standard cabinet construction method where all hardware mounting holes are drilled on a 32mm grid. This standardized spacing allows hinges, shelf pins, drawer slides, and connectors from different manufacturers to be interchangeable. CabinetSense fully supports the 32mm system and can toggle it on or off per cabinet. When the 32mm system is active, CabinetSense ensures that all line boring, hinge placement, and hardware mounting follows the 32mm grid. This guarantees that your machining output is compatible with 32mm system hardware.

docs.title: How to
docs.text: Enabling the 32mm system: The 32mm system is typically enabled at the project level through Project Settings. You can also override it per cabinet through Component Options. How it works: When enabled, CabinetSense places all line boring holes on 32mm centers. Hinge mounting plates snap to 32mm positions. Shelf pin holes align to the 32mm grid. Drawer slide mounting holes follow the 32mm pattern. All connector positions respect the 32mm grid. Reviewing compliance: CabinetSense can review and fix cabinets for 32mm compliance. The review checks that all components properly align to the 32mm grid and makes adjustments if needed.

docs.title: FAQ
docs.text: What if I do not use the 32mm system? You can disable it. CabinetSense supports both 32mm and non-32mm construction. Without 32mm, hardware positions are calculated freely based on your machining template settings. Can I mix 32mm and non-32mm cabinets in the same project? Yes. The 32mm system can be toggled per cabinet, so you can have some cabinets using 32mm and others using custom spacing. What hardware works with the 32mm system? Most European hardware manufacturers (Blum, Hettich, Grass, Hafele, etc.) produce hardware compatible with the 32mm system.

docs.title: Known Issues
docs.text: If you switch a cabinet from non-32mm to 32mm after placing hardware, you may need to Redraw the cabinet for holes to realign.

docs.title: Summary
docs.text: Bifold doors are double-hinged doors that fold in half when opened, commonly used on corner cabinets, wide pantry cabinets, and entertainment centers. CabinetSense supports bifold door configurations with special hinge handling, door matching logic, and reporting codes.

docs.title: How to
docs.text: Setting up bifold doors: Bifold doors are typically configured when defining a cabinet's door setup. Through Component Options, set the door type to include bifold. CabinetSense automatically handles the paired door panels. How bifold doors work: A bifold door consists of two panels hinged together at the center. One panel is hinged to the cabinet (the "fixed" panel) and the other panel folds against it. CabinetSense uses matching codes to pair the panels: D2D (Door to Door): Where two bifold door panels meet. D2C (Door to Cabinet): Where the bifold door meets the cabinet body. This ensures the paired doors are cut from the same material with matching grain patterns. Hinge options for bifold: Standard bifold: Uses a special 60-degree hinge option for the fold joint. Blind corner bifold: Uses a 95.1-degree hinge for the cabinet-side hinge. The Machining Database defines the specific hinge hardware for each configuration. Bifold in reports: The Cut List includes a "Bifold" flag for bifold door panels. The Millwork Report identifies bifold doors with the door pairing codes. The Hardware Report lists both the cabinet-side hinges and the fold-joint hinges.

docs.title: FAQ
docs.text: Can I use bifold doors on any cabinet? Bifold doors are most commonly used on wide openings and corner cabinets. They can technically be applied to any cabinet, but are best suited for openings wider than a single door. Do bifold doors affect the machining output? Yes. The hinge positions in the DXF output account for the bifold configuration, including the fold-joint hinge holes. Can I mix bifold and standard doors on the same cabinet? This depends on the cabinet configuration. Multi-opening cabinets can have different door types per opening.

docs.title: Known Issues
docs.text: Bifold doors on very narrow openings may not fold properly in the 3D visualization. The machining output is still correct.

docs.title: Summary
docs.text: The "Preferences..." dialog controls how CabinetSense behaves across all your projects. It is found under CabinetSense > Model > Preferences... (or the gear icon on the CS Model toolbar). Settings are organized into three groups: General, Files, and Units. Changes are saved and persist across SketchUp sessions.

docs.title: How to
docs.text: Opening Preferences: Go to CabinetSense > Model > "Preferences..." Or click the Preferences icon (gear) on the CS Model toolbar. General settings: Scene Management: On/off toggle. When on, CabinetSense automatically creates and manages SketchUp scenes for each room. Drawer Open Indicator: Controls how drawer direction is shown. Options: / (forward slash), \ (back slash), or None. Swing Indicator: Controls how door swing is shown. Options: Handle > Hinge, Handle < Hinge, or None. Model Integrity Checking: How thoroughly CabinetSense checks your model. Options: None, Carcass, Machining, or Carcass and Machining. User Profile: Choose Designer or Engineer. Language: Select the interface language (English, German, Hebrew, Polish, Thai). You can also install a new language. User Object Interior Face: Sets which face is considered the interior for user-drawn parts. Options: Left/Bottom/Front or Right/Top/Back. Explode Menus: When on, CabinetSense menu items appear directly in the Plugins and context menus instead of inside a submenu. Wall Miters?: Enable or disable automatic miter joints when cabinets meet walls. Walls Locked?: Prevents accidental movement of wall components. Component Fills Locked?: Prevents accidental changes to filler components. Auto Update Scene: Automatically updates the current SketchUp scene when you make changes. Component Alignment?: Enables automatic alignment when placing or moving components. 3D Machining Preview: Shows a 3D representation of machining operations (drilling, dadoes) directly in the model. Auto Make Unique: Automatically makes copies of components unique when you modify them. Auto Correct Redraw: Automatically corrects and redraws components when dimension changes are detected. Auto Reconnect Parts: Automatically reconnects parts that become disconnected during editing. Auto Scale Materials?: Automatically adjusts material textures when components are resized. Enable Handle Library (Beta): Enables the new handle and knob library browser. Files settings: Database Folder: Where your CabinetSense machining database is stored.

docs.title: Database Backups to keep: How many backup copies to keep.
docs.text: Materials Folder: Where your SketchUp material (.skm) files are stored. Handles Folder: Where handle and knob SketchUp component files are stored. Styles Folder: Where CabinetSense style presets are saved. Dimension Folder: Where dimensional data is stored. Units settings: Primary Units: Choose SketchUp Model Units, Inches, or Millimeters.

docs.title: FAQ
docs.text: Where are preferences saved? In a file called CabinetSense_Preferences.txt in your CabinetSense local data folder. This persists across sessions and restarts. I changed the Database Folder but my machining data is missing. When you change the folder, CabinetSense looks for the database file in the new location. Make sure you have copied the database file there. On macOS it is a .pstore file. What does Model Integrity Checking do? It checks components for problems like incorrect dimensions, missing attributes, or misaligned parts. "Carcass" checks the box structure. "Machining" checks machining operations. "Carcass and Machining" checks both. Should I enable all the Auto options? Most users benefit from having Auto Correct Redraw, Auto Reconnect Parts, and Auto Scale Materials on. Auto Make Unique is especially helpful when copying cabinets and modifying individual copies.

docs.title: Known Issues
docs.text: If the Materials Folder path is invalid, material thumbnails will not display in Job Materials. Update the path. Changing Language requires a SketchUp restart to fully take effect.

docs.title: Summary
docs.text: CabinetSense includes features for designing closet systems including wardrobe organizers, reach-in closets, and walk-in closets. Closet components have special handling for back panels, partitions, and shelving. You can toggle the visibility of closet-specific parts and manage them separately from kitchen cabinetry.

docs.title: How to
docs.text: Closet-specific components: CabinetSense library includes closet-specific components like open shelf units, hanging rod sections, drawer stacks, and shoe shelves. These components are similar to kitchen cabinets but are configured for closet dimensions and construction. Toggle closet parts: Go to CabinetSense > Multi-Component > Toggle Closet Parts. This toggles the visibility of closet-specific sub-components like backs. Useful for presentations where you want to show the closet without back panels, or for manufacturing where back panels are separate. Closet part layers: Closet parts can be assigned to a private layer using CabinetSense > Multi-Component > Private Layer. This separates closet components from kitchen components in the tag/layer system. Closet construction: Closet systems typically use different construction than kitchen cabinets: Thinner backs or no backs (wall-mounted systems). Full-height panels with shelf pin holes for adjustable shelving. Open fronts (no doors) with optional drawer fronts. Use Construction Templates to save and apply closet-specific construction settings.

docs.title: FAQ
docs.text: Can I mix closet and kitchen cabinets in the same project? Yes. Use tags and scenes to separate them visually. Export processes both types together. Can closet components export to CNC? Yes. Closet components follow the same machining and export pipeline as kitchen cabinets. How do I show a closet without doors for a presentation? Use Toggle Closet Parts or Tags to hide doors and show the interior layout.

docs.title: Known Issues
docs.text: Some closet-specific library components may have limited construction template compatibility. Check with the library documentation for supported options.

docs.title: Summary
docs.text: A Construction Template (also called a Construction Profile) is a saved set of specifications that defines how a cabinet is built. It captures everything about a cabinet's construction: which materials to use for each zone, which machining template to apply, which connectors to use, grain directions, and reveal settings. You can save templates and apply them to any cabinet, ensuring consistency across your project. Construction Templates are applied via CabinetSense > Multi-Component > Apply Construction Profile.

docs.title: How to
docs.text: Understanding construction zones: A cabinet is divided into zones, each with its own material and machining settings: Ends (Finished and Unfinished): The cabinet sides. Finished ends are visible; unfinished are against walls. Back: The back panel. Bottom: The bottom panel. Top: The top panel. Base: The base or toe kick area. Integrated Toe: A toe kick integrated into the cabinet side. Front Nailer: The strip at the top front of the cabinet. Sub-components can also be configured: Nailer, Apron, Fixed Shelf, Adjustable Shelf, Fixed Partition, Adjustable Partition. What a template includes: Cabinet style and type. Material assignment for each zone. Machining template for each zone. Connector face assignments (which face connectors are drilled from). Grain direction for each zone (horizontal, vertical, or none). Reveal settings (how much gap between doors/drawer fronts and the cabinet box). Saving a template: Configure a cabinet with your desired construction settings. Go to CabinetSense > Profiles > Save Profile... Give it a name and save. The template is stored in your Styles Folder. Applying a template: Select one or more cabinets. Go to CabinetSense > Multi-Component > Apply Construction Profile. Choose the template to apply. All selected cabinets are updated with the template's construction settings.

docs.title: FAQ
docs.text: Can I have different templates for different cabinet types? Yes. Create separate templates for base cabinets, upper cabinets, tall cabinets, vanities, etc. Does applying a template change the cabinet dimensions? No. The template only changes construction settings (materials, machining, connectors). Dimensions remain as set. Where are templates saved? In the Styles Folder configured in Preferences.

docs.title: Known Issues
docs.text: Templates are version-specific. Templates saved in an older version of CabinetSense may need to be re-saved in the current version.

docs.title: Summary
docs.text: Corner cabinets are specialized cabinet configurations designed to fit into the corners of kitchens and rooms. CabinetSense provides specific handling for corner cabinets, including adjusted dimensions, special back panel overlaps, modified joinery, and hinge options tailored for corner installations. Corner cabinets include L-shaped units, blind corner units, and diagonal corner units.

docs.title: How to
docs.text: Creating a corner cabinet: Select a corner cabinet component from the CabinetSense library. Place it in the corner of your room layout. CabinetSense automatically detects it as a corner cabinet and applies appropriate construction rules. Corner cabinet specifics: Back Panel Overlap: Corner cabinets may have back panels that overlap at the corner. CabinetSense calculates the overlap automatically. Adjusted Joinery: Some joinery patterns (like line patterns) are not applied to corner cabinet back joints due to the overlap construction. Sub-Parts: Corner cabinets may have additional sub-parts (fillers, returns) that standard cabinets do not. Blind corner cabinets: A blind corner cabinet extends past the corner, with a portion hidden behind the adjacent cabinet. CabinetSense uses a specific hinge angle (95.1 degrees) for blind corner doors to allow proper opening clearance. Filler strips are used between the blind corner and the adjacent cabinet. Corner cabinet doors: For bifold doors on corner cabinets, CabinetSense uses D2D (door-to-door) and D2C (door-to-cabinet) codes to match door pairs. Special hinge configurations allow doors to fold open without hitting each other.

docs.title: FAQ
docs.text: Can I use standard hinges on a corner cabinet? CabinetSense automatically selects the appropriate hinge angle based on the cabinet type. Blind corners use 95.1-degree hinges, while standard corners use regular hinges. How do I add a lazy susan to a corner cabinet? Lazy susan hardware can be specified through Pattern Components in the Machining Database. The hardware details appear in the Bill of Materials. Do corner cabinets export to DXF correctly? Yes. CabinetSense handles the complex geometry of corner cabinets in the DXF export, including the back panel overlaps and joinery adjustments.

docs.title: Known Issues
docs.text: Very complex corner cabinet configurations may need manual review after machining preview.

docs.title: Summary
docs.text: The "Export..." command is the main way you generate output from your cabinet design. It is found under CabinetSense > Model > Export... (also called the Dashboard). When you run an export, CabinetSense processes your entire model and produces cut lists, DXF files for CNC machines, drawer box reports, hardware lists, and material summaries. What gets generated depends on your subscription plan. Designer plans get basic model validation. Cutlist plans get cut lists, material reports, drawer box reports, and hardware reports. CNC plans get all of the above plus DXF machining files for your CNC machine.

docs.title: How to
docs.text: Running an export: Make sure your materials are assigned (via Job Materials) and your design is complete. Go to CabinetSense > Model > "Export..." or click the Export icon on the CS Model toolbar. CabinetSense scans your entire model, identifies all CabinetSense components, and generates reports. A progress bar shows the export status. When complete, the output files are saved to a folder on your computer. What gets exported: Cut List (CSV): Every part with dimensions, material, banding, grain direction, and part numbers. Send this to your panel optimizer or use it for manual cutting. DXF Files (CNC plan only): One DXF per part face with all machining operations (drill holes, dadoes, profiles, routing). These go directly to your CNC machine. Drawer Box Report: Drawer components with dimensions and slide specifications. Hardware Report: All hardware (hinges, slides, handles, knobs, connectors) with quantities. Material Summary: All materials organized by type and thickness. Millwork Report: Door profiles, face frames, and applied mouldings. Export settings (configured in Preferences...): Units: Use SketchUp Model Units or override to Inches or Millimeters. Oversize Amount: Extra material added to cut list dimensions for rough cutting. Pre-Mill Removal: Amount to remove during pre-milling. DXF Format: 2D or 3D DXF output.

docs.title: FAQ
docs.text: Which reports do I get with my plan? Designer: Model validation only. Cutlist/Plus: Cut list, drawer box report, material summary, hardware report. CNC/Professional: All of the above plus DXF machining files and millwork report. My DXF files have no machining. What is wrong? Make sure you have machining templates assigned in the Machining Database. Use "Preview Machining" from the Multi-Component menu to check before exporting. Can I export to SketchUp Layout? Yes, but that is a separate command: CabinetSense > Document > "Send to Layout..." The export is very slow. Is that normal? Export time depends on model size. Large projects with many cabinets may take several minutes. A progress bar shows status.

docs.title: Known Issues
docs.text: If components have been manually edited outside CabinetSense, the export may produce unexpected results. Run "Verify Model Integrity" first. Very large models (50+ cabinets) may cause SketchUp to slow down during export. Save your model before exporting. On macOS, DXF files use the PStore database. If machining data is missing, try "Refresh PStore" from the Machining Database.

docs.title: Summary
docs.text: G1S stands for "Good One Side." Many sheet materials like plywood and melamine have a finished (good) side and an unfinished (back) side. The G1S Material Review dialog lets you inspect each part in your model and verify that the good side is facing the correct direction. If a part has the good side facing inward or the wrong way, you can flip it right from this dialog. This is important because the good side determines which face gets the premium material finish and affects how the part appears in the cut list and machining output.

docs.title: How to
docs.text: Opening G1S Material Review: Go to CabinetSense > Model > Material Review. The system identifies parts that use G1S materials (materials with different appearances on each side). Reviewing parts: The dialog shows each G1S part with thumbnails of both sides: Side A (Good Side): The finished, visible face. Side B (Back Side): The unfinished face. For each part, verify that Side A is facing the correct direction (outward for cabinet sides, visible faces for shelves, etc.). Flipping a part: If Side A is facing the wrong direction, click the Flip button for that part. The part's A and B sides are swapped, and the material assignment updates accordingly. The change is reflected in the 3D model and all exports. Batch review: The dialog lists all G1S parts in the model so you can review them all in one session. Parts are organized by cabinet and sub-component for easy identification.

docs.title: FAQ
docs.text: How do I know which materials are G1S? G1S materials are identified by having different textures on each face. Common examples include pre-finished plywood, white melamine (white on one side, raw on the other), and wood-grain laminates with backer. Does flipping affect machining? Yes. Flipping a G1S part changes which face is considered the "outside." This affects which face gets machined and how the DXF files are generated. What if I do not use G1S materials? If all your materials are the same on both sides, this dialog will not show any parts to review.

docs.title: Known Issues
docs.text: If material thumbnails do not display, check that the material has a texture image assigned in SketchUp's Materials panel.

docs.title: Summary
docs.text: Grain Detection is a visual dialog that helps you specify the grain direction for materials applied to cabinet parts. When CabinetSense needs to know which way the grain runs on a material (horizontal, vertical, or none), it shows you a thumbnail of the material texture and lets you pick the direction. Getting grain direction right is important because it affects how parts are cut from sheet goods and how the finished cabinet looks.

docs.title: How to
docs.text: When grain detection appears: The Grain Detection dialog appears automatically when CabinetSense needs a grain direction for a material that does not have one assigned yet. It can also appear when you change materials or apply new material assignments. Choosing a direction: The dialog shows a thumbnail image of the material texture. You choose one of three options: Horizontal: The grain runs along the width of the part. Vertical: The grain runs along the height of the part. None: The material has no visible grain direction (e.g., solid colors, MDF). Click your choice and the direction is saved for that material. How grain affects output: In the cut list, grain direction is included so parts are cut with the grain running the correct way. The "Can Rotate" flag in the cut list is set based on grain — parts with grain cannot be rotated during optimization. DXF files include grain orientation for CNC setup.

docs.title: FAQ
docs.text: What if I choose the wrong grain direction? You can change it later through Material Review or by re-assigning the material in Job Materials. Does grain direction matter for all materials? Only for materials with a visible grain pattern (wood veneers, laminates). For solid colors or MDF, choose "None."

docs.title: Known Issues
docs.text: If the material thumbnail image is not available, the dialog may show a blank preview. The selection still works correctly.

docs.title: Summary
docs.text: Cabinet Groups lets you organize cabinets into logical groupings. It is found under CabinetSense > Model > Cabinet Groups (or the Cabinet Groups icon on the CS Model toolbar). Grouping is useful for large projects where you want to perform batch operations on a set of cabinets at once, like changing all doors in the upper cabinets or switching materials for the island.

docs.title: How to
docs.text: Opening Cabinet Groups: Go to CabinetSense > Model > Cabinet Groups. Or click the Cabinet Groups icon on the CS Model toolbar. Creating a group: Select one or more cabinets in your SketchUp model. In the Cabinet Groups panel, create a new group and give it a name (e.g., "Kitchen Uppers", "Island Base"). The selected cabinets are now part of that group. Using groups: Click a group name in the panel to select all cabinets in that group. Any multi-component operation you perform (Change Door/DF/Panel..., Choose New Handle..., Change Palette..., etc.) will apply to all cabinets in the selected group.

docs.title: FAQ
docs.text: What operations work with groups? Any multi-component operation: Change Door/DF/Panel..., Choose New Drawer System..., Choose New Handle..., Change Palette..., Change Height..., Redraw, Preview Machining, and Clear Machining. Do groups affect the export? No. Groups are organizational only. All visible cabinets are included in the export regardless of grouping.

docs.title: Known Issues
docs.text: If you delete a cabinet from the model, it is automatically removed from its group.

docs.title: Summary
docs.text: CabinetSense maintains a hardware library that tracks all hardware items used in your project. Hardware includes hinges, drawer slides, shelf pins, connectors, handles, knobs, and specialty fasteners. The hardware inventory is automatically calculated from the machining templates assigned to your cabinets and is included in the Hardware Report during export.

docs.title: How to
docs.text: How hardware is assigned: Hardware is not manually placed in the model. Instead, it is defined in the Machining Database templates. When you assign a machining template to a cabinet (through Construction Templates or Component Options), CabinetSense knows which hardware that cabinet requires. The number and type of hinges, slides, pins, and connectors are calculated based on the template rules and the cabinet dimensions. Hardware categories: The hardware inventory organizes items by category: Hinge Hardware: European cup hinges, mounting plates, special angle hinges. Drawer Slides: Under-mount, side-mount, or specialty slides. Shelf Pins: Support pins for adjustable shelves. Connectors: Cam locks, confirmats, dowels, knockdown fittings. Handles and Knobs: Pull handles and round knobs. Cabinet Deck Hardware: Items for decorative tops, end panels. Appliance Fasteners: Mounting hardware for built-in appliances. Viewing the hardware inventory: Hardware is summarized in the Hardware Report generated during export. The report lists each item with assembly (which cabinet), description, quantity, and dimensions. Items can be grouped by cabinet or summarized across the entire project. Customizing hardware: To change the hardware a cabinet uses, update its machining template in the Machining Database. Common changes: switching hinge types, changing slide systems, adjusting connector spacing.

docs.title: FAQ
docs.text: Can I add custom hardware items? Yes. The Machining Database allows you to define custom hardware specifications including dimensions, hole patterns, and mounting positions. Why does a cabinet show more hinges than expected? Hinge count is calculated based on door height and the hinging rules in the machining template. Tall doors automatically get more hinges. Can I create a shopping list from the hardware inventory? Yes. Export the Hardware Report to CSV and use it as a purchasing list. It includes quantities and descriptions.

docs.title: Known Issues
docs.text: Hardware manually placed as SketchUp components (not through machining templates) is not included in the hardware inventory.

docs.title: Summary
docs.text: Job Materials is where you assign real-world shop materials to the parts in your design. It is found under CabinetSense > Model > Job Materials (or the Job Materials icon on the CS Model toolbar). Every part has a material type (Carcass, Door, Drawer Box, etc.) and Job Materials lets you map each type to an actual shop material like "3/4 Maple Plywood" or "1/2 MDF."
