This is a critical step before exporting. The materials you assign here determine what shows up in your cut list, how parts are grouped for cutting, and what appears in your CNC output.

docs.title: How to
docs.text: Opening Job Materials: Go to CabinetSense > Model > Job Materials. CabinetSense scans your model and shows all material types used across your cabinets. Understanding the table: Each row represents a material type found in your model. Columns include: Material Type, Name, Nominal Thickness, Shop Material Name, Actual Thickness, Export flag, Default flag, and edge banding specifications (A, S, B, Core). Assigning materials: Click on a row to select a material type. Click the material thumbnail or name to choose a different material from your library. Set the Shop Material Name to match your shop's naming convention. Set the Actual Thickness to match your real material (this is what goes to the CNC). Configure edge banding using the A, S, B, and Core values. Saving: Click Save to apply your material assignments. All parts in the model are updated.

docs.title: FAQ
docs.text: What is Nominal vs. Actual Thickness? Nominal is the standard industry designation (e.g., 3/4"). Actual is the measured real-world thickness (e.g., 0.708" for 18mm plywood). CabinetSense uses Actual Thickness for machining calculations and CNC output. Can I set different materials for different cabinets? Job Materials applies globally by material type. For per-cabinet overrides, use "Change Palette..." from the Multi-Component menu. What does the Export checkbox do? When checked, parts with this material are included in the cut list. Uncheck to exclude certain types. Where does CabinetSense look for material files? In the Materials Folder configured in Preferences.

docs.title: Known Issues
docs.text: If Materials Folder in Preferences points to a missing folder, thumbnails will not display. After changing materials, you may need to "Redraw" cabinets for textures to update visually.

docs.title: Summary
docs.text: The Machining Database stores all the machining rules and templates that define how your cabinets are built. It is accessed via CabinetSense > Model > Machining Application (or the Machining Application icon on the CS Model toolbar). On Windows, this opens in Microsoft Access. On macOS, the database is stored in PStore format and managed within SketchUp. The database contains sections for dadoes, fasteners, line boring, hinging, drawers, cabinet deck, handles and knobs, and door profiles. Each machining template is a complete set of construction rules for a cabinet type. The "Default" template covers standard frameless 32mm construction. Available to CNC/Professional plan subscribers. Cutlist plan users can view but not modify.

docs.title: How to
docs.text: Opening the Machining Database: Go to CabinetSense > Model > Machining Application. On Windows, Microsoft Access opens with the database. On macOS, the database interface opens within SketchUp. Understanding templates: A template is a complete set of construction rules. The "Default" template is included out of the box. You can create custom templates for different construction methods or hardware brands. Database sections: Dadoes: Groove cuts for shelves, backs, and panels. Fasteners: Drilling patterns for screws, dowels, cam locks, and other connectors. Line Boring: 32mm system hole patterns on cabinet sides. Hinging: Hinge cup hole positions and clip mounting. Drawers: Drawer slide mounting and box construction. Cabinet Deck: Top and bottom deck machining. Handles and Knobs: Handle hole drilling patterns. Door Profiles: Door machining profiles for 5-piece doors.

docs.title: FAQ
docs.text: Do I need to set up the database before exporting DXF files? The "Default" template works for standard 32mm construction. Create custom templates when you need to match your specific shop methods. Can I have multiple templates? Yes. Create as many as you need for different hardware or construction methods. Can I share the database with another user? Yes. Copy the .accdb (Windows) or .pstore (macOS) file to the other user's Database Folder.

docs.title: Known Issues
docs.text: On macOS, refresh the PStore after importing from a Windows .accdb file using "Refresh PStore." The database path must be correctly set in Preferences.

docs.title: Summary
docs.text: Review Materials provides a detailed audit of all material assignments across your entire model. It is found under CabinetSense > Model > Review Materials (or the Review Materials icon on the CS Model toolbar). Unlike Job Materials which assigns materials broadly by type, Review Materials shows every individual part and its material assignment, letting you fine-tune on a part-by-part basis. This is useful for catching mistakes before export, such as a shelf with the wrong thickness or a door with the wrong material.

docs.title: How to
docs.text: Opening Review Materials: Go to CabinetSense > Model > Review Materials. Understanding the table: Columns: Type, Material, Nominal, New Nominal, Template, Part, Lock, Count. Each row shows a unique material assignment found in the model. Making changes: Enter a new value in the "New Nominal" column to change the thickness for a group of parts. Use the Lock checkbox to prevent specific assignments from being changed by bulk operations. Click Process to apply changes. CabinetSense updates all affected parts. Using Lookup: Click a row and use the Lookup button to highlight those parts in your SketchUp model, so you can visually verify which parts are affected.

docs.title: FAQ
docs.text: What is the difference between Job Materials and Review Materials? Job Materials assigns materials broadly by type. Review Materials shows individual part-level assignments and lets you make targeted changes. What does the Lock checkbox do? It prevents that material assignment from being changed by bulk operations like Change Palette or Job Materials updates.

docs.title: Known Issues
docs.text: In very large models, Review Materials may take a few seconds to load. If you change materials in both Job Materials and Review Materials, the last operation applied takes precedence.

docs.title: Summary
docs.text: When you open a SketchUp model that was created with an older version of CabinetSense, the Model Conversion system automatically detects the version difference and upgrades your model to be compatible with the current version. This is also accessible via CabinetSense menu > Upgrade Model. The upgrade process updates component attributes, machining data, and internal structures to match the current version while preserving your design.

docs.title: How to
docs.text: Automatic conversion: When you open a model saved with an older CabinetSense version, the system detects the version mismatch. You are prompted to upgrade the model. Click Yes to run the conversion. A progress bar shows the update status. Once complete, your model is compatible with the current version. Manual upgrade: Go to the CabinetSense menu and click "Upgrade Model." CabinetSense checks your model and applies any needed upgrades. If your model is already current, you see: "Your components are current." If upgrades were applied, you see: "Your components have been upgraded." Upgrading the library: Go to the CabinetSense menu and click "Upgrade Library..." This upgrades your component library files to the current version.

docs.title: FAQ
docs.text: Will upgrading change my design? The upgrade process preserves your design. It updates internal data structures and attributes to match the current version. Your cabinet dimensions, materials, and layout remain the same. Can I open a converted model in an older version of CabinetSense? Converted models may not be fully compatible with older versions. It is recommended to keep a backup before upgrading. Do I need to upgrade every time I update CabinetSense? Not necessarily. Minor updates may not require model conversion. CabinetSense checks automatically and only prompts when needed.

docs.title: Known Issues
docs.text: Very old models (multiple major versions behind) may take longer to convert. After conversion, it is recommended to run Verify Model Integrity to check for any issues.

docs.title: Summary
docs.text: "Verify Model Integrity" is a diagnostic tool that checks your SketchUp model for problems before you export. It is found under CabinetSense > Model > Verify Model Integrity (or the checkmark icon on the CS Model toolbar). It checks for incorrect dimensions, missing materials, disconnected parts, misaligned components, and invalid machining configurations. Running this before export is strongly recommended. It catches problems that would otherwise result in incorrect cut lists or failed CNC operations.

docs.title: How to
docs.text: Running the check: Go to CabinetSense > Model > Verify Model Integrity. CabinetSense scans your model and lists any issues found. If no issues are found, you see: "No issues were detected with your CabinetSense component(s)." Understanding results: Issues are listed by cabinet and part. Each issue includes a description and a suggested fix. Common issues: parts with invalid dimensions, parts not connected to their parent cabinet, unassigned materials, machining operations referencing missing templates. Integrity levels (configured in Preferences...): None: No automatic checking. Carcass: Checks cabinet box structure (dimensions, connections, alignment). Machining: Checks machining operations (templates, holes, dadoes). Carcass and Machining: Checks both (recommended).

docs.title: FAQ
docs.text: Do I need to run this before every export? It is highly recommended, especially after making changes. What does "disconnected part" mean? A component that is no longer properly linked to its parent cabinet. This can happen from manual moves or copies outside CabinetSense. Use "Reconnect Component" from the Component menu to fix. Can I export even if there are issues? Yes, but results may be incorrect for parts with unresolved issues.

docs.title: Known Issues
docs.text: Can be slow on very large models (100+ cabinets). Some warnings are informational and do not necessarily indicate a problem.

docs.title: Summary
docs.text: Pattern Components are user-defined hardware and accessory documentation entries in CabinetSense. They let you specify hardware items that are not part of the standard machining database but need to appear on the Bill of Materials (BOM) report. Examples include pullout pantry inserts, lazy susan mechanisms, waste bin kits, and other specialty accessories.

docs.title: How to
docs.text: What pattern components are for: When you install specialty hardware in a cabinet (lazy susan, pullout tray system, integrated waste bin), CabinetSense may not have a specific machining template for it. Pattern Components let you document these items so they appear on the Hardware Report and BOM. Setting up a pattern component: In the Machining Database, navigate to the Pattern Components section. Define the component with: Description: What the hardware is. Quantity: How many are needed per cabinet. Dimensions (optional): Width, height, depth. Assign the pattern component to cabinets through the machining template. Auto-rotate option: Some pattern components need to rotate 180 degrees to align with the cabinet's coordinate system (especially when the component is glued to a specific face). Enable Auto-Rotate when the component needs to flip based on its mounting face. Interior/Exterior side: Pattern components can specify whether they are mounted on the interior or exterior of a cabinet part. This affects which face the associated machining operations appear on in the DXF output.

docs.title: FAQ
docs.text: Do pattern components show in the 3D model? Pattern components are primarily documentation items for the BOM. They may not have 3D geometry in the SketchUp model unless you manually place a representative component. Can I create a pattern for a custom pull-out system? Yes. Define it as a Pattern Component with the appropriate description and quantity. It will appear on the Hardware Report.

docs.title: Known Issues
docs.text: Pattern components do not generate machining operations. They are for BOM documentation only.

docs.title: Summary
docs.text: Profile Rendering visualizes door profiles directly in your 3D model. It is found under CabinetSense > Model > Profile Rendering (or the Profile Rendering icon on the CS Model toolbar). When you run this, CabinetSense draws the door profiles (for 5-piece doors) as 3D geometry in the model so you can see how they will look before sending to the CNC machine.

docs.title: How to
docs.text: Running Profile Rendering: Go to CabinetSense > Model > Profile Rendering. CabinetSense scans the model for doors with profiles assigned and renders them in 3D. This is a visual preview only — it does not modify the machining data.

docs.title: FAQ
docs.text: Do I need this if I buy pre-made doors? No. Profile Rendering is useful only if you machine door profiles in-house.

docs.title: Known Issues
docs.text: Complex profiles may take a moment to render in large models.

docs.title: Summary
docs.text: Project Settings define the default values and specifications for your entire project. These settings apply to all new cabinets added to the model and include things like the default machining template, overlay amounts, drawer slide preferences, wall dimensions, and job information (client name, address, etc.). Project Settings ensure consistency and save you from configuring each cabinet individually.

docs.title: How to
docs.text: Key project-level settings: 32mm Nominal Thickness: The default material thickness for 32mm system calculations. Frameless Overlay: The overlay amount for frameless cabinet doors and drawer fronts. Full Overlay Amounts: Full overlay and half overlay amounts for door sizing. Drawer Slide Drilling: Default slide system for drawer mounting. Max Plate Thickness: Maximum mounting plate thickness for hinges. Default Door Profile: The default profile for 5-piece doors. Default Machining Templates: Default templates for dado, fastener, line boring, hinging, drawer, and cabinet deck operations. Handle Machining: Whether handle hole machining is included by default. Arch Settings: Default arch parameters (shoulder, height, top, bottom). Wall settings: Wall Height: Default height for walls drawn with the Wall Tool. Wall Thickness: Default wall thickness. Wall Protrusions: Up to two protrusions per wall with distance from floor, height, and depth. Job information: Project Title, Work Order Number. Client Name, Address, Phone Number. Designer Name, Sales Person, Contractor. These fields appear in export reports and Layout documents.

docs.title: FAQ
docs.text: Do Project Settings override individual cabinet settings? Project Settings provide defaults for new cabinets. Individual cabinets can be modified through Component Options or Multi-Component operations. Existing cabinets are not changed when you update Project Settings. Where do I set job information? Job information is part of the Project Settings and is used in export reports and Layout documents.

docs.title: Known Issues
docs.text: If you change Project Settings mid-project, only new cabinets pick up the new defaults. Existing cabinets retain their original settings.

docs.title: Summary
docs.text: "Delete Construction Lines" removes all SketchUp construction lines (guide lines and guide points) from your model. It is found under CabinetSense > Model > Delete Construction Lines (or the Delete Construction Lines icon on the CS Model toolbar). Construction lines are useful during design but can clutter the model for presentation and export.

docs.title: How to
docs.text: Deleting construction lines: Go to CabinetSense > Model > Delete Construction Lines. All construction lines and guide points in the model are removed.

docs.title: FAQ
docs.text: Can I undo this? Yes. Use SketchUp's Undo (Ctrl+Z / Cmd+Z) immediately after to restore the construction lines. Does this affect CabinetSense components? No. Only SketchUp construction lines and guide points are removed. CabinetSense components are not affected.

docs.title: Known Issues
docs.text: This removes all construction lines in the model, not just in a selected area. If you need to keep some, undo and manually delete the ones you do not need.

docs.title: Summary
docs.text: Scene Management automatically creates and manages SketchUp scenes (pages) for your project. It is found under CabinetSense > Model > Scene Management (or the Scene Management icon on the CS Model toolbar). It can be toggled on or off. When on, CabinetSense creates scene tabs for each room based on the room numbers assigned to your cabinets.

docs.title: How to
docs.text: Toggling Scene Management: Go to CabinetSense > Model > Scene Management. Click to toggle it on or off. You can also enable it in Preferences... under General settings. How scenes are organized: Each cabinet has a room number (e.g., A, B, C). CabinetSense creates a scene tab for each room, showing only the cabinets assigned to that room. Scene names follow the format: "Room Number) Description." Navigating between scenes: Click on scene tabs at the top of the SketchUp viewport to switch between rooms. Camera position, zoom, and tag visibility are saved with each scene.

docs.title: FAQ
docs.text: Can I create my own scenes alongside CabinetSense scenes? Yes. CabinetSense manages its own scenes and will not interfere with manually created ones. But avoid modifying CabinetSense-created scenes as they may be overwritten. How do I change the room number for a cabinet? Select the cabinet, open Component Options, and change the room number field. Can I use scenes to control what gets exported? CabinetSense processes visible cabinets during export. By switching to a specific scene, you control which cabinets are included.

docs.title: Known Issues
docs.text: If you manually rename or delete CabinetSense-managed scenes, they may be recreated on the next update.

docs.title: Summary
docs.text: Scribe strips and filler strips are used to close gaps between cabinets and walls or between adjacent cabinets. A scribe is a piece of material that is scribed (cut to fit) against an uneven wall surface. A filler strip fills a gap between two cabinets. CabinetSense handles both scribes and fillers with specific banding codes, dimensions, and layer management.

docs.title: How to
docs.text: Scribe strips: When placing cabinets against an uneven wall, you may need a scribe strip on the end panel. Set the scribe banding option in the Change Door/DF/Panel dialog or through Component Options. Scribe banding uses the code "X" in the cut list to indicate which edges need scribing. The scribe thickness is configurable and affects DXF export — parts are notched to accommodate the scribe. Filler strips: Fill Space is a CabinetSense function that creates filler strips between cabinets. Go to CabinetSense > Component > Fill Space. Select the gap between two cabinets, and CabinetSense creates a filler component to close it. The filler inherits the material of the adjacent cabinet or can be assigned its own material. Managing filler visibility: Filler strips are assigned to the Filler tag/layer (_csFiller). Toggle this tag to show or hide all filler strips in the model. Useful for presentations vs. manufacturing views. Door fillers: A "Door Filler" attribute (Yes/No) determines whether the filler extends behind the door overlay. When set to Yes, the filler is sized to fill the full cabinet opening, not just the gap between boxes.

docs.title: FAQ
docs.text: When should I use a scribe vs. a filler? Use a scribe when a cabinet end meets an uneven wall and the edge needs to be custom-cut to fit. Use a filler when there is a gap between two cabinets that needs a flat strip to close it. Do fillers appear in the cut list? Yes. Filler strips are included in the cut list with their dimensions, material, and banding information. Can I resize a filler after placing it? Yes. Select the filler and adjust its dimensions through Component Options.

docs.title: Known Issues
docs.text: Filler strips placed manually (not through Fill Space) may not be tracked in the CabinetSense inventory.

docs.title: Summary
docs.text: The "3D" command toggles the camera between a 3D perspective view and a 2D plan (top-down) view. It is found under CabinetSense > Model > 3D (or the 3D icon on the CS Model toolbar). This is a quick way to switch between design views without manually adjusting the SketchUp camera.

docs.title: How to
docs.text: Toggling the view: Go to CabinetSense > Model > 3D. Or click the 3D icon on the CS Model toolbar. Click once to switch to 3D perspective. Click again to switch back to 2D plan view.

docs.title: FAQ
docs.text: Does this change my saved scenes? No. This only changes the current camera view. Saved scenes retain their own camera positions.

docs.title: Known Issues
docs.text: If Scene Management is on, the view may revert when you click a scene tab.

docs.title: Summary
docs.text: The Transform tool converts SketchUp components that were not created with CabinetSense into CabinetSense-compatible components. This is useful when you have imported components from the 3D Warehouse, a manufacturer's catalog, or your own custom-built SketchUp components and want them to work with CabinetSense features like export, machining, and material management. The Transform tool is accessed via CabinetSense > Component > Transform.

docs.title: How to
docs.text: Using the Transform tool: Select one or more SketchUp components that are not CabinetSense components. Go to CabinetSense > Component > Transform. CabinetSense analyzes the selected components and converts them. What Transform does: Auto-detects dimensions: Reads the component's bounding box to determine width, height, and depth. Assigns material thickness: Detects the material thickness from the component geometry. Sets grain direction: Assigns an initial grain direction based on the component proportions. Creates banding attributes: Generates edge banding information for the cut list. Creates material attributes: Links the component's SketchUp material to CabinetSense material tracking. Makes the component unique: Each transformed component becomes a unique CabinetSense instance. After transforming: The component now appears in CabinetSense export reports (cut list, hardware report). You can use CabinetSense operations on it (Change Material, Equalize, Resize, etc.). Material Review and G1S review will include the transformed component.

docs.title: FAQ
docs.text: Can I transform any SketchUp component? The Transform tool works best with simple box-like components (panels, shelves, backs). Complex geometry may not convert perfectly. Will Transform change the appearance of my component? No. Transform adds CabinetSense attributes to the component without changing its geometry or appearance. Can I undo a Transform? Yes. Use SketchUp's Undo (Ctrl+Z / Cmd+Z) immediately after transforming to revert.

docs.title: Known Issues
docs.text: Components with very complex geometry may have inaccurate dimension detection. Check the component options after transforming. Nested components (components inside components) may not transform correctly. Explode them first.

docs.title: Summary
docs.text: Wall protrusions represent obstacles on walls that cabinets need to fit around. Common examples include baseboard moulding, chair rails, electrical panels, plumbing risers, and closet hanging systems. CabinetSense allows you to define up to four wall protrusion zones per cabinet, and during CNC export, the affected parts are automatically notched to clear the protrusion.

docs.title: How to
docs.text: Defining a wall protrusion: Wall protrusions are configured in Project Settings or per-cabinet through Component Options. Each protrusion requires three measurements: Distance from Floor: How high up the wall the protrusion starts. Height: The vertical size of the protrusion. Depth: How far the protrusion sticks out from the wall. How many protrusions: You can define up to 4 protrusion zones per cabinet. This allows for multiple obstacles at different heights (e.g., a baseboard at the bottom and a chair rail in the middle). Effect on CNC output: When you export DXF files, CabinetSense automatically generates notches in the back edges of cabinet side panels where they meet the protrusion. This ensures parts fit around the obstacle without manual measuring and cutting. Wall height: The wall height setting (in Project Settings or per-wall) works together with protrusions to define the full wall profile from floor to ceiling.

docs.title: FAQ
docs.text: Do wall protrusions appear visually in the SketchUp model? Wall protrusions affect the DXF machining output but may not always show as 3D geometry in the model. They are primarily a machining feature. Can I have different protrusions on different walls? Yes. Each cabinet can have its own protrusion settings, so cabinets on different walls can have different protrusion configurations. What if my baseboard is at the floor? Set the Distance from Floor to 0, the Height to the baseboard height, and the Depth to the baseboard thickness. The cabinet sides will be notched at the bottom back edge.

docs.title: Known Issues
docs.text: Protrusions only affect back-edge notching. They do not automatically adjust cabinet depth or position.

docs.title: Summary
docs.text: The Wall Tool lets you draw walls directly in SketchUp as a starting point for your kitchen or room layout. Walls are special CabinetSense components that cabinets snap to and align against. When you place cabinets against a wall, CabinetSense automatically handles alignment and mitering at wall intersections. The Wall Tool is available under SketchUp's Tools menu as "Wall" and also has its own CS Wall Tool toolbar.

docs.title: How to
docs.text: Activating the Wall Tool: Go to the SketchUp Tools menu and select "Wall." Or click the Wall icon on the CS Wall Tool toolbar. Your cursor changes to the Wall drawing tool. Drawing a wall: Click to set the starting point of the wall. Move your mouse to define the wall direction and length. Click again to place the wall endpoint. The wall is created as a CabinetSense component with configurable height and thickness. Wall properties: Wall Height: Set in Project Settings or when drawing. Wall Thickness: Standard wall thickness. Wall Protrusions: You can define up to two protrusions (bulkheads, soffits) per wall with distance from floor, height, and depth. Wall mitering: When two walls meet at a corner, CabinetSense automatically creates a miter joint if "Wall Miters?" is enabled in Preferences. This keeps corners clean and realistic. Locking walls: Enable "Walls Locked?" in Preferences to prevent accidentally moving walls after placing them.

docs.title: FAQ
docs.text: Do I need to draw walls before placing cabinets? No. Walls are optional. You can place cabinets freely in the model. However, walls provide a useful visual reference and help with alignment. Can I edit a wall after placing it? Yes. Select the wall and use Component Options to change its height, thickness, or other properties. Can I hide walls to see just the cabinets? Yes. Use CabinetSense > Tags > Wall Tag to toggle wall visibility.

docs.title: Known Issues
docs.text: Wall intersections with complex angles may not miter perfectly. Manual adjustment may be needed.

docs.title: Summary
docs.text: The About section of the Machining Database displays version information for CabinetSense and the machining database. This includes the software version, build number, database version, and other technical details. This information is useful when contacting support or verifying that you are running the correct version.

docs.title: How to
docs.text: Accessing About: Open the Machining Database. Navigate to the About section. You will see: CabinetSense version, build number, and database version.

docs.title: FAQ
docs.text: How do I know if my database is up to date? Compare the database version shown in About with the latest version mentioned in the release notes.

docs.title: Summary
docs.text: Bulk Copy lets you duplicate an entire machining template or set of machining data within the database. This is useful when you want to create a new template that is similar to an existing one — you copy the existing template and then modify only the parts that differ, rather than building from scratch.

docs.title: How to
docs.text: Accessing Bulk Copy: Open the Machining Database. Navigate to Bulk Copy. Select the source template to copy from. Enter a name for the new template. The entire configuration (dadoes, fasteners, line boring, hinging, drawers, etc.) is duplicated. Modify the new template as needed.

docs.title: FAQ
docs.text: Does Bulk Copy create an independent template? Yes. The new template is completely independent. Changes to one do not affect the other.

docs.title: Known Issues
docs.text: Make sure to give the new template a distinct name to avoid confusion.

docs.title: Summary
docs.text: The Cabinet Deck section of the Machining Database defines the machining for the top and bottom panels (decks) of a cabinet. This includes connector holes, dado positions, and any special machining required for how the deck connects to the sides, back, and face frame.

docs.title: How to
docs.text: Accessing Cabinet Deck settings: Open the Machining Database. Navigate to the Cabinet Deck section. Key settings: Machining rules for the top deck and bottom deck. Connector positions for joining decks to cabinet sides. Dado alignment for back panels that slot into the deck.

docs.title: FAQ
docs.text: Are top and bottom decks configured separately? They share the same section but can have different machining depending on your template configuration. For example, the bottom deck might have additional holes for leveler legs.

docs.title: Known Issues
docs.text: If deck machining appears misaligned, check the dado and connector settings for the template.

docs.title: Summary
docs.text: Change Drill Holes allows you to modify the drill hole specifications for existing machining operations in the database. This is useful when you switch to a different hardware brand that requires different hole diameters or depths, or when you need to fine-tune hole positions.

docs.title: How to
docs.text: Accessing Change Drill Holes: Open the Machining Database. Navigate to Change Drill Holes. Select the holes you want to modify and update the diameter, depth, or position values. Save your changes.

docs.title: FAQ
docs.text: Will changing drill holes affect existing projects? Changes apply to future exports. Existing DXF files are not retroactively updated. Re-export to generate new files with the updated holes.

docs.title: Known Issues
docs.text: Double-check hole changes against your hardware specifications before running production.

docs.title: Summary
docs.text: Change History tracks modifications made to the Machining Database over time. This lets you see what was changed, when, and by whom. It is useful for auditing changes and understanding why machining output may have changed between exports.

docs.title: How to
docs.text: Accessing Change History: Open the Machining Database. Navigate to Change History. View the log of changes with timestamps and descriptions.

docs.title: FAQ
docs.text: Can I undo a change from the history? Change History is a log for reference. To undo a change, you would need to manually revert the values or restore from a database backup.

docs.title: Known Issues
docs.text: History entries are stored within the database. If you replace the database file, the history is replaced too.

docs.title: Summary
docs.text: Dadoes are grooves cut into cabinet parts to hold shelves, backs, bottoms, and partitions. This section of the Machining Database defines how dado cuts are configured for your machining templates. CabinetSense supports three types: Dado (through), Blind Dado (stopped before the edge), and Lock Rabbet (stepped groove for mechanical joints). When you export for CNC, CabinetSense automatically generates the correct dado cuts on each part based on these rules.

docs.title: How to
docs.text: Accessing Dado settings: Open the Machining Database (CabinetSense > Model > Machining Application). Navigate to the Dadoes section. Types of dadoes: Dado (Through): Groove runs the full width or length. Used for fixed shelves and partitions. Blind Dado: Groove stops before reaching the edge. Used when you do not want the groove visible from the front. Lock Rabbet: Stepped groove providing a mechanical lock. Common for drawer construction. Configuration properties: Depth Allowance: How deep the dado is cut. Width Allowance (Inside/Outside): Extra width for material thickness variations. Length Allowance: Extra length for the dado. Stop At: Where a blind dado stops (distance from edge). Mortise: Whether a mortise is added at the dado end. Relief: Small gap at the bottom for glue squeeze-out. Cutter Allowance Width: Extra width for the cutting tool.

docs.title: FAQ
docs.text: How does CabinetSense know where to place dadoes? It calculates positions based on cabinet geometry and the positions of shelves, backs, and partitions. You do not place dadoes manually. Can I have dadoes on both sides of a part? Yes. CabinetSense generates machining for both faces. For example, a cabinet side might have dadoes for the top, bottom, back, and shelves on different faces. What is Relief? A small gap at the bottom of the dado to allow for glue squeeze-out. Typical values are 1/32" or 1mm.

docs.title: Known Issues
docs.text: If width allowances are set incorrectly, parts may not fit. Test settings with a sample part before production. On macOS, run "Refresh PStore" after importing dado settings from Windows.

docs.title: Summary
docs.text: The Door Profiles section of the Machining Database defines the machining paths for 5-piece doors (doors with rails, stiles, and a center panel). Each profile specifies the routing paths, depths, and tool strategies for cutting the door profile on a CNC router. This section is only relevant if you are making your own doors in-house.

docs.title: How to
docs.text: Accessing Door Profile settings: Open the Machining Database. Navigate to the Door Profiles section. Key settings: Profile Name: The name identifying this door profile. Machining Paths: Each profile consists of one or more paths, each with a layer, strategy, face, reference point, offset, depth, and box dimensions. Layer: The CNC layer the path is assigned to in DXF output. Strategy: The routing strategy (e.g., climb cut, conventional cut). Rendering profiles in the model: Use CabinetSense > Model > Profile Rendering to visualize door profiles in 3D on your model.

docs.title: FAQ
docs.text: Do I need Door Profiles if I buy pre-made doors? No. Door Profiles are only needed if you are routing door profiles in-house on a CNC machine.

docs.title: Known Issues
docs.text: Complex profiles with many paths may take longer to render in 3D preview.

docs.title: Summary
docs.text: The Drawers section of the Machining Database defines how drawer slide systems are machined. This includes the mounting holes for the slide on the cabinet side, notch dimensions for the drawer box, and how drawer fronts are positioned. CabinetSense supports various slide brands and styles and automatically generates all necessary machining based on the rules defined here.

docs.title: How to
docs.text: Accessing Drawer settings: Open the Machining Database. Navigate to the Drawers section. Key settings: Slide System: The specific slide brand and model being used. Back Notch (Height/Width): Dimensions of the notch at the back of the drawer box for the slide. Front Notch (Height/Width): Dimensions of the notch at the front of the drawer box. Mounting Holes: The hole pattern drilled into the cabinet side for slide mounting. Drawer Front Locating: How the drawer front is positioned relative to the drawer box, configured by drawer height.

docs.title: FAQ
docs.text: Can I use different slide systems for different cabinets? Yes. Assign different machining templates with different slide configurations to different cabinets. How does CabinetSense know where to place the slide holes? The hole positions are calculated from the drawer opening dimensions and the slide system specifications in the database.

docs.title: Known Issues
docs.text: Always verify slide hole positions against the manufacturer's installation guide for your specific slide model.

docs.title: Summary
docs.text: The Fasteners section of the Machining Database defines how cabinet parts are physically connected. This includes drilling patterns for screws, dowels, cam locks (Minifix, Rafix), confirmat screws, and other mechanical connectors. CabinetSense automatically calculates and places all fastener holes during export based on these rules. Fastener settings are organized into sub-sections: Fastening Method Pattern, Connector Pattern, Line Routing Pattern, Connector Face, Fastening Methods List, and Connector List.

docs.title: How to
docs.text: Accessing Fastener settings: Open the Machining Database. Navigate to the Fasteners section. Sub-sections: Fastening Method Pattern: The overall drilling pattern for a joint type (e.g., top-to-side, shelf-to-side). Connector Pattern: The specific hole pattern for a particular connector (e.g., Minifix, Confirmat). Line Routing Pattern: Routing grooves for connectors that require a channel. Connector Face: Which face of the part the connector is mounted on. Fastening Methods List: All available fastening methods you have configured. Connector List: All connectors with their specifications (hole diameter, depth).

docs.title: FAQ
docs.text: Can I use different fasteners for different parts of the cabinet? Yes. The template lets you specify different methods for different joints. Do I manually place fastener holes? No. CabinetSense calculates and places all holes automatically based on your template.

docs.title: Known Issues
docs.text: If connector hole positions appear incorrect in DXF output, check the Connector Pattern offsets.

docs.title: Summary
docs.text: The Handles and Knobs section of the Machining Database defines the drilling patterns for mounting handles and knobs on doors, drawer fronts, and panels. Each handle entry specifies the hole diameter, depth, and spacing (bore distance) so CabinetSense can automatically generate the correct mounting holes during export.

docs.title: How to
docs.text: Accessing Handle settings: Open the Machining Database. Navigate to the Handles and Knobs section. Key settings: Handle Length: The overall length of the handle. Handle Width: The overall width. Bore Distance: The distance between the two mounting holes (for bar-style handles). Drill Face: Which face of the door/panel the holes are drilled from. Hole Diameter and Depth: Specifications for each mounting hole. Pocket dimensions (if applicable): For handles that require a routed pocket. Assigning handles to cabinets: Use "Choose New Handle..." from the Multi-Component menu to apply a handle to selected cabinets. The handle machining is automatically applied based on the database configuration.

docs.title: FAQ
docs.text: Can I use different handles for different cabinets? Yes. Use "Choose New Handle..." from the Multi-Component menu to apply handles to specific cabinets or groups. What about knobs that only need one hole? Knobs are configured with a single mounting hole. The bore distance is zero.

docs.title: Known Issues
docs.text: Make sure the bore distance matches the actual handle. An incorrect bore distance will result in misaligned holes.

docs.title: Summary
docs.text: The Hinging section of the Machining Database defines how door hinges are machined. This includes the cup hole on the door (for concealed European-style hinges), the mounting plate holes on the cabinet side, and the spacing rules for multiple hinges. CabinetSense automatically calculates hinge positions based on door height and the rules you define here.

docs.title: How to
docs.text: Accessing Hinging settings: Open the Machining Database. Navigate to the Hinging section. Key settings: Top Hinge: Distance from the top of the door to the top hinge center. Bottom Hinge: Distance from the bottom of the door to the bottom hinge center. Max Span: Maximum distance between hinges before a third (span) hinge is added. Hinge Clip: Name of the hinge clip/mounting plate used (e.g., "32mm Hinge Clip"). Layer: CNC layer assignment for hinge machining in DXF output. Template: Which machining template this hinging configuration belongs to. How it works during export: CabinetSense reads the door height. Places top and bottom hinges at the configured distances from the edges. If the span between top and bottom hinges exceeds Max Span, a middle hinge is added. Hinge cup holes are generated on the door face. Mounting plate holes are generated on the cabinet side.

docs.title: FAQ
docs.text: Can I use different hinges for different door sizes? Yes. You can configure hinging rules that vary by template. Assign different templates to different cabinets. How many hinges does CabinetSense add? Typically two (top and bottom). If the door is tall enough that the span exceeds Max Span, a third hinge is added automatically.

docs.title: Known Issues
docs.text: Make sure hinge cup hole diameter matches your specific hinge brand. Most European hinges use a 35mm cup hole, but this varies.

docs.title: Summary
docs.text: The Import feature in the Machining Database lets you bring in machining data from another CabinetSense database. This is useful for sharing machining configurations between users, migrating data from one computer to another, or restoring from a backup.

docs.title: How to
docs.text: Accessing Import: Open the Machining Database. Navigate to Import. Select the source database file (.accdb on Windows, .pstore on macOS). Choose which templates or data sections to import. Confirm the import. The data is added to your current database.

docs.title: FAQ
docs.text: Will importing overwrite my existing data? Imported data is added alongside your existing data. If template names conflict, you may need to rename them. Can I import from Windows to macOS? You need to convert the .accdb file to .pstore format. Use "Refresh PStore" after importing.

docs.title: Known Issues
docs.text: Large databases may take a few moments to import.

docs.title: Summary
docs.text: The Joinery section of the Machining Database handles how parts are joined together using dowels, connectors, and drilling patterns. While the Fasteners section defines the connector hardware specs, Joinery defines the actual drilling operations that happen during machining — where the dowel holes go, which patterns to use, and how connectors interact with the 32mm system.

docs.title: How to
docs.text: Accessing Joinery settings: Open the Machining Database (CabinetSense > Model > Machining Application). Navigate to the Joinery section (may be part of Fasteners depending on your database version). Key joinery operations: Doweling: Drilling dowel holes at part joints. Includes pre-pattern and post-pattern drilling for precise alignment. Connector Placement: Positioning cam locks, confirmats, or other connectors at joints. Line Pattern Drilling: Drilling a series of holes along a line for continuous joinery. 32mm-aware joinery: When the 32mm system is active, joinery operations snap to the 32mm grid. How joinery works during export: CabinetSense reads the joinery configuration from the machining template. It determines which joints exist in each cabinet (top-to-side, bottom-to-side, shelf-to-side, etc.). For each joint, it applies the configured joinery operation and generates the drill holes in the DXF output.

docs.title: FAQ
docs.text: What is the difference between Joinery and Fasteners? Fasteners define the hardware specifications (hole sizes, depths). Joinery defines the drilling operations and patterns used during machining. Can I use both dowels and connectors in the same cabinet? Yes. Different joints within the same cabinet can use different joinery methods.

docs.title: Known Issues
docs.text: If joinery holes appear in the wrong positions, check both the Fasteners and Joinery configurations for the active machining template.

docs.title: Summary
docs.text: Line boring is the 32mm system drilling pattern — the rows of evenly spaced holes drilled into cabinet sides. These holes are used for adjustable shelf pins, hinge mounting plates, and drawer slide brackets. The Line Boring section of the Machining Database defines the hole diameter, spacing, inset distances, and drilling pattern for your specific construction method.

docs.title: How to
docs.text: Accessing Line Boring settings: Open the Machining Database (CabinetSense > Model > Machining Application). Navigate to the Line Boring section. Key settings: Hole Diameter: Size of each bore hole (typically 5mm for shelf pins). Vertical Spacing: Distance between holes (32mm in the standard 32mm system). Center Point Insets: Distance from the front edge, back edge, and intermediate rows. White Space: Undrilled distance from top and bottom of the cabinet side. Drill Direction: Which face the holes are drilled from. Balanced Drilling: Whether the hole pattern is symmetrical top-to-bottom. Corner 45° and Corner Back: Options for corner cabinet configurations.

docs.title: FAQ
docs.text: What is the 32mm system? An industry-standard construction method where all holes are spaced 32mm apart. This allows hardware from different manufacturers to be interchangeable. Can I change the hole spacing? Yes. While 32mm is standard, you can configure any spacing in the database. What are the center point insets? These define how far each row of holes is from the front and back edges of the cabinet side. The front row is typically 37mm from the front edge in the 32mm system.

docs.title: Known Issues
docs.text: If line boring patterns do not align with your hardware, check the inset distances and spacing values.

docs.title: Summary
docs.text: Refresh PStore rebuilds the macOS PStore database from the source data. On macOS, CabinetSense uses PStore (.pstore) instead of Microsoft Access (.accdb). If you have imported data, migrated from Windows, or suspect the database is out of sync, running Refresh PStore ensures the database is correct and up to date.

docs.title: How to
docs.text: Accessing Refresh PStore: Open the Machining Database. Navigate to Refresh PStore. Click to refresh. CabinetSense rebuilds the PStore file from the current data.

docs.title: FAQ
docs.text: When should I run Refresh PStore? After importing data from a Windows .accdb file. If machining data appears missing or incorrect on macOS. After a database update or migration. Will this delete my data? No. It rebuilds the PStore from the existing source data. Your configurations are preserved.

docs.title: Known Issues
docs.text: This feature is only relevant on macOS. Windows users use the .accdb file directly.

docs.title: Summary
docs.text: Connector Face specifies which face of a cabinet part a connector is mounted on. In cabinet construction, connectors can be installed from the face (flat surface) or the edge of a part. This setting tells CabinetSense where to place the machining operations for each connector.

docs.title: How to
docs.text: Accessing Connector Face settings: Open the Machining Database. Navigate to Fasteners > Connector Face. Configuration: Each entry specifies a part type and which face the connector is drilled from. Face drilling means the hole goes into the flat surface of the panel. Edge drilling means the hole goes into the edge (thickness) of the panel.

docs.title: FAQ
docs.text: Why does it matter which face the connector is on? The CNC machine needs to know which side of the part to drill. Face drilling and edge drilling require different tool orientations and are placed on different layers in the DXF output.

docs.title: Known Issues
docs.text: Incorrect face assignment results in holes on the wrong side of the part. Double-check face settings when configuring new connectors.

docs.title: Summary
docs.text: The Connector List is a master list of all hardware connectors defined in your Machining Database. Each connector entry includes the physical specifications: hole diameter, hole depth, minimum part thickness required, and any special properties. Connectors are referenced by Fastening Method Patterns and Connector Patterns.

docs.title: How to
docs.text: Accessing the list: Open the Machining Database. Navigate to Fasteners > Connector List. Each entry includes: Connector name (e.g., "Minifix 15mm", "Confirmat 7x50", "8mm Dowel"). Hole diameter and depth for the source part. Target hole diameter and depth for the mating part. Minimum part thickness required. Any special offset or configuration values. Adding a new connector: Click Add and enter the connector specifications from the hardware manufacturer's data sheet. Once added, create a Connector Pattern for it and reference it in a Fastening Method.

docs.title: FAQ
docs.text: Where do I get the specifications for a new connector? From the hardware manufacturer's technical data sheet. You need at minimum the hole diameter and depth for both parts.

docs.title: Known Issues
docs.text: Connector specifications must be entered precisely. Even small errors can cause assembly problems.

docs.title: Summary
docs.text: A Connector Pattern defines the specific hole layout for a particular hardware connector. For example, a Minifix cam lock requires a large cup hole on one part and a pilot hole on the mating part. The Connector Pattern specifies the exact hole diameters, depths, and positions for each connector type.

docs.title: How to
docs.text: Accessing Connector Patterns: Open the Machining Database. Navigate to Fasteners > Connector Pattern. Each pattern defines: The hole diameters for the source part (the part the connector body sits in) and the target part (the mating part). The hole depths for each. The offset distances from part edges. Whether the pattern is for face drilling or edge drilling.

docs.title: FAQ
docs.text: What is the difference between source and target? The source part is where the main connector body sits (e.g., the cam lock housing). The target part is where the mating hole is drilled (e.g., the bolt hole in the adjoining panel).

docs.title: Known Issues
docs.text: Make sure hole diameters exactly match your hardware specifications to avoid loose or tight fits.

docs.title: Summary
docs.text: A Fastening Method Pattern defines the overall drilling pattern used for a specific type of joint in a cabinet. For example, one pattern might define how the cabinet top connects to the sides, while another pattern defines how a fixed shelf connects to the sides. Each pattern specifies which connector to use, how many holes to drill, and how they are spaced.

docs.title: How to
docs.text: Accessing Fastening Method Patterns: Open the Machining Database. Navigate to Fasteners > Fastening Method Pattern. Each pattern defines: The joint type it applies to (e.g., top-to-side, bottom-to-side, shelf-to-side). Which connector is used for this joint. The hole spacing and count. Whether additional holes are needed for specific part configurations.

docs.title: FAQ
docs.text: Can I create different patterns for different joint types? Yes. Each joint type in the cabinet can have its own fastening method pattern. How do patterns relate to connectors? A pattern references a specific connector from the Connector List. The connector defines the hole diameter and depth, while the pattern defines the layout and positioning.

docs.title: Known Issues
docs.text: Changing a pattern affects all cabinets using that machining template. Test changes on a sample before applying to a full project.

docs.title: Summary
docs.text: The Fastening Methods List is a master list of all the fastening methods you have configured in the Machining Database. Each method represents a complete way of joining two parts, referencing a specific connector and its drilling pattern. From this list, you can see at a glance all the joining methods available in your machining templates.

docs.title: How to
docs.text: Accessing the list: Open the Machining Database. Navigate to Fasteners > Fastening Methods List. Each entry shows: The method name (e.g., "Minifix Top/Bottom", "Dowel Shelf", "Confirmat Side"). Which connector it uses. Which joints it applies to. Adding a new method: Create the connector in the Connector List first. Create a Connector Pattern for it. Then add a new Fastening Method that references the connector and pattern.

docs.title: FAQ
docs.text: Can I have multiple methods in the same template? Yes. A template can use different methods for different joints within the same cabinet.

docs.title: Known Issues
docs.text: Deleting a method that is referenced by a template will cause machining errors. Remove the reference first.

docs.title: Summary
docs.text: A Line Routing Pattern defines the routing groove or channel needed for certain connectors. Some fastening systems require a groove routed along the edge or face of a part in addition to drill holes. This pattern specifies the groove width, depth, and position.

docs.title: How to
docs.text: Accessing Line Routing Patterns: Open the Machining Database. Navigate to Fasteners > Line Routing Pattern. Each pattern defines: The groove width and depth. The position of the groove relative to part edges. Which face or edge the groove is routed on. The CNC layer the groove is assigned to in the DXF output.

docs.title: FAQ
docs.text: When do I need a Line Routing Pattern? When your connectors require a groove in addition to drill holes. Not all fastening methods need routing.

docs.title: Known Issues
docs.text: If groove dimensions do not match your connector hardware, the parts may not assemble correctly.

docs.title: Summary or Overview
docs.text: This document provides detailed information about CabinetSense licensing, activation, and license management. It covers essential aspects of licensing, including how to activate your license, manage licenses, and troubleshoot common licensing issues.

docs.title: Activating Your License
docs.text: Launch CabinetSense software. Navigate to the License section in the software. Click on the 'Activate License' button. Enter your license key in the designated field. Click 'Activate' to complete the activation process.

docs.title: Managing Licenses
docs.text: To manage licenses, go to the License section in the software. Here, you can view details about your current license, including expiration date and activation status. To deactivate a license, click on the 'Deactivate License' button and follow on-screen instructions.

docs.title: 1. How do I purchase a CabinetSense license?
docs.text: To purchase a CabinetSense license, visit our official website and select the desired license package. Complete the purchase process, and you will receive a license key via email.

docs.title: 2. Can I transfer my CabinetSense license to another computer?
docs.text: Yes, you can transfer your license to another computer. Deactivate the license from the current computer and activate it on the new computer using the same license key.

docs.title: 3. What happens if my license expires?
docs.text: If your license expires, you will no longer have access to premium features of CabinetSense software. Contact our support team to renew your license.

docs.title: 4. How many computers can I activate my CabinetSense license on?
docs.text: Each CabinetSense license is valid for a single computer. Contact support if you need to transfer the license to another computer.

docs.title: 5. Can I use CabinetSense software offline?
docs.text: CabinetSense software requires an internet connection for license activation. However, once activated, you can use the software offline for a limited period before reactivation is required.

docs.title: Tutorials on How to Use Specific Functions
License Activation Tutorial
docs.text: SketchUp models: N/A Database references: N/A Video tutorials: CabinetSense License Activation Tutorial Narrative explanations: Follow the step-by-step guide to activate your CabinetSense license seamlessly.

docs.title: Known Issues
docs.text: Some users may experience difficulties activating their license due to firewall restrictions. Ensure that your firewall settings allow CabinetSense software to communicate with our licensing servers. In rare cases, license activation emails may be delayed. Check your spam folder and contact support if you do not receive your license key promptly. By following these guidelines, users can effectively manage their CabinetSense licenses and ensure uninterrupted access to the software's features.

docs.title: Support
docs.text:
Welcome to the Support section.

Use the navigation menu on the left to explore the available topics.

docs.title: Summary
docs.text: The "Check for Update..." feature lets you see if a newer version of CabinetSense is available and download it from within SketchUp. Keeping your software up to date ensures you have the latest features, bug fixes, machining templates, and component libraries. You can also separately update your component library and materials library through the Help submenu.

docs.title: How to
docs.text: Checking for a software update: Go to the CabinetSense menu at the top of SketchUp. Click "Check for Update..." CabinetSense connects to the update server and compares your current version with the latest available version. If an update is available, you will see the new version number and a prompt to download. Click Download to begin the update process. After the download completes, restart SketchUp to load the new version. Updating your component library: Go to CabinetSense menu, then Help, then "Get the latest Library..." Follow the prompts to download and install the latest library files. Updating your materials library: Go to CabinetSense menu, then Help, then "Get the latest Materials Library..." Follow the prompts to download new material textures and configurations. Reinstalling CabinetSense: Go to CabinetSense menu, then Help, then "Reinstall CabinetSense..." This downloads and reinstalls the full application.

docs.title: FAQ
docs.text: How do I know which version I am running? The version and build number are displayed on the CabinetSense start panel when SketchUp loads. You can also check the About section in the Machining Database. Will updating affect my existing projects? No. Updates are backward-compatible. Your existing models and configurations will continue to work. Do I need an internet connection? Yes. An internet connection is required to check for and download updates. Is there a separate update for the Materials Library? Yes. You update the materials library separately through CabinetSense menu > Help > "Get the latest Materials Library..."

docs.title: Known Issues
docs.text: If your internet connection is slow, the download may time out. Try again with a stable connection. After a major update, the first load of CabinetSense may take slightly longer as it initializes new components.

docs.title: Summary
docs.text: The "Contact Support..." feature lets you send a message directly to the CabinetSense support team without leaving SketchUp. You can describe your issue, attach files, and include screenshots. CabinetSense automatically sends your software version, build number, operating system, and SketchUp version along with your message to help the team diagnose problems faster. A support ticket is created with a unique number (e.g., CS-1234) and you receive an email confirmation. You can track your ticket, add comments, and view responses through the CabinetSense web portal.

docs.title: How to
docs.text: Sending a support request from SketchUp: Go to the CabinetSense menu at the top of SketchUp. Click "Contact Support..." (or use the envelope icon on the CabinetSense toolbar). A support dialog opens inside SketchUp. Enter your name, email address, and a description of your issue. Attach your SketchUp model or screenshots if relevant. Click Send. What happens after you submit: A support ticket is created with a unique number (e.g., CS-1234). You receive an email confirmation with your ticket number. The support team reviews your request and responds via email. You can reply to the email or track the ticket on the CabinetSense web portal.

docs.title: FAQ
docs.text: How long does it take to get a response? Standard support requests are usually addressed within one to two business days. Priority Support subscribers receive faster responses. Can I attach my SketchUp model? Yes. When submitting from SketchUp, you can attach your .skp file directly. This is highly recommended as it helps the team see exactly what you are working on. What information should I include? Describe what you were trying to do, what happened instead, and any error messages. Your software version and OS are sent automatically when you submit from within SketchUp. Can I track the status of my ticket? Yes. You receive a ticket number and can track it through the CabinetSense web portal where you can see the status, add comments, and view responses.

docs.title: Submitting a Support Request
docs.text: Go to CabinetSense menu, then click "Contact Support..." Fill in the form with your details and a clear description. Attach any relevant files. Click Send and note your ticket number.

docs.title: Known Issues
docs.text: An internet connection is required. If you are offline, you will see a message asking you to connect first. Very large file attachments may take longer to upload depending on your connection speed.

docs.title: Summary
docs.text: The "Licence..." menu item lets you manage your CabinetSense licence. Your licence is tied to your CabinetSense account and determines which features you can access based on your subscription plan. From this dialog you can activate your licence on a new computer, view your plan type and expiry date, and manage registrations. CabinetSense supports multiple plan types: Trial (14 days full access), Designer/Essentials (basic design), Cutlist/Plus (design plus reports), and CNC/Professional (full CNC machining output).

docs.title: How to
docs.text: Accessing your licence: Go to the CabinetSense menu at the top of SketchUp. Click "Licence..." The licence dialog shows your account email, plan type, expiry date, and registration count. First-time activation: When you first open SketchUp after installing CabinetSense, you are prompted for your email address. Enter the email you used when you registered for CabinetSense. The system validates your account and activates the licence automatically. Transferring your licence to a new computer: Each account has a licence quota (typically 2 machines). If you exceed the quota, contact support to have an old registration removed. Install CabinetSense on your new computer and enter your account email to activate.

docs.title: FAQ
docs.text: How many computers can I use CabinetSense on? Typically 2 computers per licence. Contact support if you need to adjust this. What happens when my trial expires? After the 14-day trial, CabinetSense prompts you to purchase a subscription. Some advanced features are restricted until you subscribe. My licence is not being recognized. What should I do? Make sure you are connected to the internet. Licence validation requires a server connection. If the problem persists, contact support with your account email. Can multiple users share one subscription? Yes, through the parent-child account system. A parent account can invite team members who each get their own licence slot.

docs.title: Known Issues
docs.text: If you are behind a corporate firewall, licence validation may fail. Contact your IT department to allow connections to the CabinetSense server. After a SketchUp update, the licence may need to re-validate. Restart SketchUp and it should activate automatically.

docs.title: Summary
docs.text: The "Make an Appointment..." feature lets you book a live session with a CabinetSense support specialist or trainer directly from SketchUp. This is useful for hands-on guidance, walking through a complex project, or real-time help. Appointment availability depends on your plan. Priority Support subscribers and users with prepaid training credits have access to dedicated calendar slots.

docs.title: How to
docs.text: Booking an appointment: Go to the CabinetSense menu at the top of SketchUp. Click "Make an Appointment..." (or use the calendar icon on the CabinetSense toolbar). A calendar dialog opens showing available time slots. Select a date and time. Confirm the appointment. You receive a confirmation email with the meeting link or call details. Types of appointments: Regular Support: Available to all active subscribers. Priority Support: Dedicated time slots for Priority Support subscribers. Prepaid Training: Bookable if you have purchased training credits.

docs.title: FAQ
docs.text: How long are the appointments? Regular support sessions are typically 15 to 30 minutes. Prepaid training sessions can be longer depending on your credits. Do I need to pay extra? Regular support is included with active subscriptions. Priority Support requires a Priority Support subscription. Training sessions require prepaid training credits. Can I cancel or reschedule? Yes. Use the link in your confirmation email. Please give at least 24 hours notice. What if my time zone is different? The calendar automatically adjusts to your local time zone.

docs.title: Known Issues
docs.text: An internet connection is required to access the calendar. Some corporate firewalls may block the calendar page.

docs.title: Summary
docs.text: The "Buy..." menu item opens the CabinetSense online store where you can purchase or upgrade your subscription. CabinetSense offers several plans: Designer/Essentials (basic cabinet design), Cutlist/Plus (design plus reports), and CNC/Professional (full CNC output). You can also purchase additional licences and training credits.

docs.title: How to
docs.text: Accessing the store: Go to the CabinetSense menu at the top of SketchUp. Click "Buy..." (or use the shopping cart icon on the CabinetSense toolbar). The online store opens showing available plans and pricing. Choosing a plan: Designer/Essentials: 3D cabinet design, scenes, and basic visualization. Cutlist/Plus: Everything in Designer plus cutlist reports, material management, and drawer box reports. CNC/Professional: Everything in Cutlist plus DXF export, CNC machining output, hardware reports, and full machining database access. Completing the purchase: Select your plan and complete payment through FastSpring (the secure payment processor). Your licence is upgraded automatically after payment. Restart SketchUp to activate the new features.

docs.title: FAQ
docs.text: What payment methods are accepted? Major credit cards and PayPal through FastSpring. Can I upgrade my plan later? Yes. You can upgrade at any time. The price difference is prorated. What happens if I cancel? Your plan stays active until the end of your paid period. After that, advanced features are restricted. Can multiple users share one subscription? Yes, through the parent-child account system. The parent account can invite team members with individual licence slots.

docs.title: Known Issues
docs.text: An internet connection is required to access the store. After purchasing, restart SketchUp if new features are not showing.

docs.title: Tutorials
docs.text:
Welcome to the Tutorials section.

Use the navigation menu on the left to explore the available topics.

docs.title: Summary
docs.text: This guide walks you through the essential steps to get up and running with CabinetSense. CabinetSense is a plugin for SketchUp that turns it into a complete cabinet design, engineering, and manufacturing solution. Whether you are a one-person shop or a large manufacturer, CabinetSense handles everything from 3D design to CNC-ready output. CabinetSense works with SketchUp 2021 and later, on both Windows and macOS.

docs.title: How to
docs.text: Installation: Download the CabinetSense installer from the CabinetSense website or through the Help menu if you already have an older version installed. Run the installer and follow the prompts. CabinetSense files are placed in your SketchUp Plugins folder. On macOS: ~/Library/Application Support/SketchUp [version]/SketchUp/Plugins/CabinetSense On Windows: C:\Users[username]\AppData\Roaming\SketchUp\SketchUp [version]\SketchUp\Plugins\CabinetSense First Launch: Open SketchUp. CabinetSense loads automatically and shows a start panel. Enter your CabinetSense account email to activate your licence. The start panel shows your plan type, version, and build number. CabinetSense toolbars appear: CabinetSense (main), CS Model, CS Component, CS Multi Component, CS Document, CS Tags, CS Presets, CS Wall Tool, and CS Profile. Setting Up Preferences: Go to CabinetSense > Model > Preferences... Set your Language if not English. Set the Database Folder to where your machining database is stored. Set the Materials Folder to where your .skm material files live. Choose your Primary Units (SketchUp Model Units, Inches, or Millimeters). Enable Scene Management if you want automatic scene creation for each room. Placing Your First Cabinet: Open or create a new SketchUp model. From the SketchUp Components panel, browse the CabinetSense component library. Drag a cabinet component into your model. Click on the cabinet to select it, then go to CabinetSense > Component > Component Options to configure its dimensions, materials, and settings. Assigning Materials: After placing cabinets, go to CabinetSense > Model > Job Materials. Assign shop materials to each material type in your model. Set actual thicknesses and edge banding. Click Save. Previewing Machining: Select one or more cabinets. Go to CabinetSense > Multi-Component > Preview Machining. CabinetSense shows 3D drill holes, dadoes, and other operations in the model. Use Clear Machining to remove the preview. Exporting: Go to CabinetSense > Model > Export... CabinetSense generates cut lists, DXF files, hardware reports, and more. Files are saved to a folder on your computer.

docs.title: FAQ
docs.text: Do I need SketchUp Pro? CabinetSense works with both SketchUp Pro and SketchUp Studio. Some features like Send to Layout require SketchUp Pro with Layout. What SketchUp versions are supported? SketchUp 2021 and later. Can I use CabinetSense on both Windows and macOS? Yes. CabinetSense works on both platforms. The main difference is the Machining Database format: .accdb (Microsoft Access) on Windows and .pstore on macOS. How do I get the component library? Go to CabinetSense > Help > "Get the latest Library..." to download the latest component library. Where can I learn more? CabinetSense > Help > Online Help opens the online documentation. CabinetSense > Help > Videos opens the YouTube tutorial channel. CabinetSense > Help > Getting Started Help opens the beginner's guide. Use "Make an Appointment..." to book a live training session.

docs.title: Your First Cabinet Project
docs.text: Open SketchUp and create a new model. Set your model units (e.g., inches or millimeters). From the Components panel, find the CabinetSense library. Drag a base cabinet into the model. Select it and open Component Options to set dimensions. Drag an upper cabinet and position it above. Open Job Materials and assign shop materials. Run Export... to generate your cut list.

docs.title: Understanding the Toolbars
docs.text: CabinetSense (main): Buy..., Make an Appointment..., Contact Support..., Online Help, Tutorials... CS Model: Export..., Preferences..., Cabinet Groups, Job Materials, Review Materials, Verify Model Integrity, Scene Management, Machining Application, Profile Rendering, 3D, Delete Construction Lines. CS Component: Component Options, Vertical/Horizontal Cabinet Openings, Fill..., Resize..., Face Me, Align, Toggle Door Opening, Toggle Number of Doors, Create Connector. CS Multi Component: Change Door/DF/Panel..., Preview Machining, Clear Machining, Choose New Drawer System..., Choose New Handle..., Change Palette..., Change Height..., Redraw, Private Layer, Toggle Closet Parts, Apply Construction Profile, Make Unique, Hide/Unhide, Transform. CS Document: Send to Layout..., Add Outside/Inside Dimensions, Clear Dimensions, Assign Part #'s, Show/Clear Part Numbers, Find Part Number. CS Tags: Individual tag toggles for each part type, plus CabinetSense Tags (all). CS Presets: Style presets (Concept, Design, Construction, Diagram, Presentation) and Tag presets (Carcass, Frontage, Drawer, External, Room Only, Hide Room, Presentation).

docs.title: Known Issues
docs.text: On first install, CabinetSense may take a moment to initialize. Subsequent loads are faster. If toolbars do not appear, go to SketchUp > View > Toolbars and enable the CabinetSense toolbars. Language files are stored separately. If translations are missing, go to Preferences and reinstall the language pack.
